review_title: Great work/life balance... but going woke
pros: Three weeks of vacation per year, plus the full week of Christmas off. They want your time outside of the work day to be YOUR time, so they generally respect the 8-5 or 9-5 time slot and don't expect you to be answering emails after-hours or on the weekend. They try to do lots of social events and maintain a healthy culture. Many people become friends outside of work. For new hires, there's lots of programs to help you engage with other young people and build friendships. They also have mentorship and other training programs so you can learn from leaders and other co-workers with more experience. Most people are very friendly and always willing to help.
cons: Because of COVID-19, they have suspended their 401k match program as well as their Inspire Recognition monetary rewards, at least for the time being. They also have not even let young, healthy people return to the office with masks and social distancing. Unless you're working directly on hardware, you're working remote. This makes it hard to build relationships, especially as a new hire. The worst part is the introduction of Critical Race Theory to multiple aspects of the company. They have a new required training course this year that pushes far left racial politics. They promote "How to Be an Antiracist" by Ibram X. Kendi in the course, and they expect you to acknowledge your "white privilege" and fight for the leftist social changes they prescribe. They are also working to revise all of their documents and code to get rid of "racial/gender language." Some examples of these words are blacklist, whitelist, man-power and rule of thumb. None of these are discriminatory, yet they expect you to change the English language to fit their political agenda. I do not think I could bring up any of these concerns with my manager without it having a severe effect on my career. This makes me worried about the future of the company.

review_title: Working at the Greenplum consulting division of Dell-EMC
pros: 1. Plenty of learning opportunities. 2. Many clients nationwide and also abroad 3. Good health and 401K benefits
cons: 1. Management does not care about welfare of employees. They would ask you to work for three companies at the same time if it works for them. Burn-out is common for their most productive employees as they seek to maximize revenue from them. 2. On the same note, management has little faith in its technical consultants. They would not hesitate to put them in most difficult situations in front of the client if it suits them. 3. Promotions are quite arbitrary, seniority and contributions are less important than who know and likes who. 4. Management changes every year.

pros: Numerous roles and responsibilities allow for room to move and grow. I was originally hired as a manufacturing manager in 1995 and was able to work my way into IT as a Business Analyst then work my way into a Software Developer position. Great benefits. I spent nearly 25 years with the company prior to COVID related reductions in force.
cons: Many of the individual contributor technical roles have moved overseas and what remains in the United States would be considered leadership and administrative. The international aspect of teams leads to expectations of long hours and long weeks. Extremely demanding environment which has evolved from the feel of a start-up to very corporate.

pros: Good range of compensation and benefits
cons: The company is doing a reorganization almost every year and there is a lot of retrenchment. Your manager this year will promise promotion and the following year you are considered redundant after doing all the automation and hard work.

pros: Good wl balance, average compensation, good rd opportunities

pros: Dell takes care of it's employees pretty well. They are one of the few companies left that does 1:1 matches up to 6% for your 401k. The company is extremely open to remote work, and there are a lot of really great people working here. We are provided professional training every year, and before the pandemic, at least one major conference every year in addition to several smaller, local conferences. The work-life balance is amazing at Dell, and it's a HUGE reason people don't leave, especially those with families/young kids.
cons: Dell still stack-ranks employees, so inevitably people will get screwed, even if everyone on the team does an equal job. Dell also makes it very hard to get promoted to i9, which is basically the same as a Sr. level anywhere else. But i8s are also considered Sr. anywhere else, and there is a huge difference in the bonus % between i8 (8%) and i9 (15%). Also, Dell doesn't pass out RSUs to everyone like most of the other big tech companies do, so that's a big negative when you're in the tech space. The insurance isn't all that great -- it could definitely be worse, but for a company the size of Dell, you'd expect better insurance/pricing.

pros: There are more than enough opportunities to learn and acquire new skills at Dell. You will be encouraged to expand your skills and to learn. Job responsibilities can change quickly, so be prepared to take advantage as windows open.
cons: Dell is a large organization in which groups within business orgs frequently encounter political pressures that require a lot of skill and will power as you navigate obstacles. For example, another team may view your work as countering their priorities and thus may rally support against your good work. If you work in a leading edge tech area you may see shifting sands and a may move from team to team quickly. This change frequently appears a bit disjoint. Don't get disheartened - press ahead!

review_title: EMC merger still an issue, unsatisfying products
pros: Good pay when raises aren't frozen. Still the industry leader although in a dying industry. First couple of layers of management is really good.
cons: This applies to legacy EMC teams. Everyone is still feeling the effects of the merger than happened 4 years ago. There are so many redundant teams no one knows which sales team to go to for help. The fact that there are so many redundant teams is what has caused the wave of endless layoffs. Internal sales tools are still disparate and the attempted consolidation has only caused more problems. It's painful to have to use 5+ tools to find information that should be found using 1. The portfolio is still too extensive and confusing for customers and it's consolidation has been too slow. This just isn't an interesting industry anymore. New product releases just offer more performance and more storage. The big 3 cloud providers are way more interesting places to work and actually frequently innovate with exciting products. I'd recommend trying to work there instead.

pros: Cab service was good. Good Security staff. Clean bathrooms. The training staff is one of the best I have seen. Kudos to them. (Sadly you don’t be dealing with them after the training)
cons: 1) The managers keep changing every now and then. And the manager who is appointed is someone who will not stand for the employees and because of which we would be crossed skilled to different teams even though you still report to one manager. This can happen at any time which makes us very uncertain of the job that we would doing when we login. 2) Although you aren’t technically hired for sales they would still expect you to make revenue if you end up in out of warranty team. Now they used to keep us extra benefit if you meet/exceed the revenue target to keep the spirits high but not anymore. So there’s technically no point in making revenue since it’s the management that reaps the benefits. 3) If you are someone who prefers travelling on own vehicle car or bike and are doing a shift that falls between 10am - 9pm then forget the safety of your vehicle. You would end up having more scratches than paint on it. This is partly because they haven’t upgraded the parking and it’s way over crowded. Good luck finding a space to park your vehicle. ALSO YOU WOULD HAVE TO PAY FOR PARKING! 4)The top management hides behind the front management (folks that we deal with) to get make sure they meet their numbers while top management would either be gaming or travelling. Yes they do not have a special lobby for managers but they sure as hell know how to pretend to be good in front and squeeze the you for all the work you can physically provide for them. Bottom line please do not get into dell as a Sr technician or jr technician if you care of keeping your self happy.

review_title: Not as great as it used to be
pros: Work-life balance, remote working opportunity, generally good people to work with.
cons: As of writing 3 re-orgs this year alone. Promise of "opportunities" at each re-org, results in opportunities for those already in management - Individual contributors get left behind. Benefits had been cut to where 401K is no longer matching. Very political environment when working with other orgs. No standard for advancement/promotion; it's a moving target, where some people get promoted for just breathing, while others do duties and functions 2-3 levels above their paygrade, and don't get a consideration.

pros: It was good while it lasted, lots of work to do
cons: Middle management jockey around with each other trying to get promoted and killing the spirit of individual contributors.

He lacks vision and puts himself first and the organization's growth second - which is unacceptable.

review_title: Great company to work for. Lot of opportunity and very ethical
pros: Full disclosure: have worked for Dell for 17+ years. 1) Opportunities. Have moved roles every 18-24 months since I joined constantly learning something new and being challenged 2) Ethical company: really focuses on doing what is right from CEO down to the employee resource groups spread across the globe 3) Working environment: great environment work work in terms of team members, leaders. Not sure it was like this 10 years ago but certainly now
cons: 1) Very driven environment: there is a culture of constantly growing and developing. If you are just looking to coast you would struggle 2) Benefits: I find the benefits good but I know other team members that have come in have said they are not as competitive as their previous companies

review_title: A great place to work but culture is beggining to change
pros: - Real focus on work life Balance - Good packages and a willingness to pay sales people that perform - Great technology and services in a number of areas - Clear, well articulated go to market strategy - Some super talented people
cons: The merger of Dell and EMC over 3 years ago, meant the coming together of two very large companies and two very different company cultures - particularly in the sales organization. I came from the historic Dell side of the business from a culture I absolutely loved. That culture has undoubtably changed over the last 3 years and as the company moves forward, it will be interesting to see the direction the company takes in this area.

review_title: Exceptional company to learn and grow at all times
pros: Dell Technologies provides people the opportunity to take on new challenges both within your role and within your campus. You have to demonstrate the willingness to take on these challenges and bring people with you. There is a great culture of inclusiveness, diversity, collaboration and opportunity to grow. People are provided the opportunity to move across multiple functions through job rotation, job shadowing. Dell continuously provide opportunity to learn new skills to enhance you to deliver in your role for today and tomorrow.
cons: Not necessarily a Con but Dell Technologies are a results driven company. People joining Dell need to understand that if you wish to progress your career in Dell. Its how you deliver the results will determine your career. Follow the Dell Culture Code and bring people with you and you will succeed.

pros: - Great Work/Life Balance - Flexible schedule - pre-Covid could work from home 2/3days a week. - Amazing manager and leadership team. They support and encourage you! - Company culture is top notch. They value you; personal time, high ethic standards, and development opportunities. - Excellent response to Covid. -5mo maternity leave. - Vast portfolio of services and products with many moving parts, so you don’t get bored. I’ve really enjoyed being at Dell.
cons: Despite the lack of typical tech perks, benefits, and compensation, I believe the quality of life at Dell is exceptional. - Healthcare is good, but it’s not totally included ($0) like other big tech. - No free food or drinks. You can easily spend $11 on lunch at HQ. The coffee cafe is not free. I imagine this is because so many people WFH, but it could be subsidized. - No stock. I’ve been told higher levels get stock. This is a big con considering that other big tech employees are making $$$ on their RSU/stock options. -Lower salary than other big tech. - Promotions are 3-5yrs.

pros: Having remote work, benefits before covid-19, overall friendly workplace.
cons: Covid-19 has really shown the true colors of this company, Dell has canceled all benefits due to the pandemic to "preserve cash." This has to be one of the dumbest statements I have ever heard after a company goes through 2 quarters of the year with absolutely insane profits, better than ever before. Is the company going to look into changing things like at least 401K matching back, no, nothing is being looked into, just a heartfelt email thanking its employees for making them a ton of money. It might look like the executives are good giving up their salary, but that doesn't even begin to breathe on the money they are actually making in stock options ect. So they are hoarding this money in fear of the recession. News flash, you hoard money, your 150+ thousand employees are no longer spending as much, and the places they went to don't have as much money so they stop spending, and everyone stops spending, places closes and the economy crashes. So thank you Dell for contributing to the economic recession amid making billions in profit so far this year.

review_title: Perfect place to work, learn, and grow
pros: The best storage company in the world, after acquiring EMC, now they have hardware, software, and solutions. Technical writing team at Dell is huge. The best part here is majority of the managers are best to work with. They don't believe in micromanaged. Every year, all the employees have to take a survey called Tell Dell where they can raise their voice against anything. This process refines the company each year. This survey gets some points for all the managers and there is a limit set whithin which if a manager gets, he/she has to undergo some corrective actions. The engineering team understands the values of Technical doc and really helps. Depending on the managers, most of the teams are flexible. You can work from home. The employer really values employees and their personal life. From May to August, we have summer hours; even Friday second halves are off. You come up with a new idea or process improvements, people always welcome it. A well authoring system in place. You can suggest any modifications. Company encourages applying for other opportunities within the company through IJP. Except the pay (which is not bad) and perk, everything else is the best.
cons: Pay is not that good. No perks. Yearly hike is also okok. No discount on Dell Product. They sell refurbished laptop, on bidding, and that to on high price. Cretch is free for lady employees only, from an employer like Dell who always believes in equal opportunity, I don't expect this.

review_title: Great place to work for, pay not as competitive
pros: Great work life balance and great work culture if you are fortunate enough to get aligned to the right org. Very diverse portfolio of products to sell and a lot of perks in terms of free "swag" and free lunch all the time
cons: Some organizations and teams can be very difficult depending on the mid level management as they can tend to micromanage and care solely about metrics. There also tends to be a lot of change in compensation plans (what you get paid for and what you don't). There is not great collaboration with the EMC side of the business and oftentimes will try and cannibalize each other because of how these compensation plans are set up. Pay is not as competitive if you try and get promoted internally into bigger roles. you almost have to leave and come back to Dell to get an offer more aligned to market value/expectations

review_title: Deception after deception... Lots of fake promises
pros: - The possibility to apply internally - The escalation process which makes people reactive - Free transportation to and from the company for interns (ANAPEC)
cons: - Lots of fake promises: I have been an intern with a miserable salary for a YEAR now. Normally interns don't exceed a period of 6 Months before getting an indefinite Contract. The upper Management was promising me the contract for 6 Months now just for me to stay, until I receive an official email from the company stating that all hiring and promotions will be suspended until the next Fiscal Year... My Non-Renewable 2 Years contract will expire then... I wish the manager was honest from the beginning so I could look for a job elsewhere! - Interns don't get to speak up: There's a survey that is sent annually to all staff. I've been working with Dell for a year now but I cannot take the survey because I am an intern (under ANAPEC contract)... I have never felt so belittled in my WHOLE LIFE!!!! If I can advise you something NEVER accept a Fixed-term contract (ANAPEC) with Dell. Either accept an Indefinite Term contract or don't work there.

My peers and broader team at Dell are also very collaborative and supportive. In addition to the people, my benefits, pay and work/life balance are all positives.

pros: I'm nearly 10 months into the program and looking back can see how much I have gained and grown in this fairly short amount of time as a result of the program. The biggest pro's are: +Lots of new opportunities to develop technical and soft skills. +Accelerates the growth of your professional network. +Program flexibility to your needs for development. +Working with amazing and interesting people. +Interesting time to be a part of the "Technology Industry" which is growing exponentially. +Freedom to explore and improvise within the program. +Company Culture Overall I am very pleased with the program thus far, looking forward to what the future holds...
cons: Overall its a great program for graduates and like all similar finance programs, you'll always find areas that can be improved. It's also very subjective, for me personally the pro's easily outweigh the cons in this program. In addition, if you find any cons the program sponsors/leads are open to listen and make changes accordingly.

pros: -friendly work environment -opportunity to work outside of the specific role and participate on various events and projects also for other departments -easy networking if you are a person for such thing -support of volunteering activities for community -further education and training courses -mentorship and advice from more senior colleagues -bonus plan framework
cons: -within the program you are not able to use the full extent of flexibility, which is provided by the company -no ability to rotate to other than finance department, which I think would be really good to get the whole picture about how the company works and improve, simplify and create more effective processes -work/ life balance is more work oriented within the program, because some of the job positions are more demanding, plus there are curricular activities for the program. (But after all, it is a graduate program to help you start your career, so its ok.)

pros: I was headhunted to work at Dell and I am very glad I took that leap of faith and transitioned to this organisation. Dell are a forward thinking organisation and strive to ensure they move with the demands of the Global and Customer needs, whilst keeping disruption to a minimum. I work in Dell Technologies Select, this area of the business focus's on Transformational Change (IT/Digital/Workplace) for Dells top 100 customers, which means this role has a lot of exposure and interest across the organisation and Account Teams. Despite the size and scale there is a warm family feel about it and people really do look out for and support each other. Despite DT being a huge company you don't feel like a small fish in a big pond. Communication from the Executive Leadership Team is excellent and regular, they want to know what is happening at ground level and encourage feedback and asking questions. As a remote worker I am provided with all the tools I need to execute my role and meet mine and customer objectives. The opportunities within Dell are many and varied, since I've been working for Dell I've spent time working onsite in the US for one of their major customers. Since the world has faced the Covid-19 pandemic Dell has been true to their core values and the level of support they have provided to their employees has been wonderful. I am glad I made the move to Dell.
cons: Nothing that causes me concern at this time.

pros: Finance Graduate Program is a great start for fresh graduates because it develops you very fast in a very short time with various challenges, occasions. I would list the pros as below: -Being challenged by various projects, competitive analyses, presentations, elevator pitch. You also get some responsibilities require leadership in this very young age. It is very busy schedule, but it was really worth it. -Feedback from manager, program leads, colleagues, sponsors, peers. Therefore, you get a holistic view of yourself, your strengths and your weaknesses. You understand which areas you need to work on. And, you will always find many people ready to help you. You feel supported, not just in words, for real. -Company invests in your development. You feel being valued as an employee. If you like working and development, it is really full of opportunities. -Broad networking opportunity due to program and its events. From Day 1, you are exposed to senior management and executives. -The opportunity to continue from more advanced programs: Finance Development Program, Accounting Development Program, Tax Development Program -You are assigned mentor and you have the opportunity to have regular 1x1 meetings with program sponsors, directors. -Gym in the building is a big plus. -Culture is very positive and supportive. Positivity starts spreading from leadership, firstly from Michael Dell :)
cons: -Besides the program activities, not every FGPs' individual role is the same. Everybody is assigned to different roles and role is taking most of the time. The work load of the roles can be closer to each other than now. -The program is normally designed for 1 year. However, there is an opportunity to continue from more advanced program after 6 moths. Although this is beneficial because it brings a huge motivation, sometimes the group focuses on this more than it is needed.

pros: all listed benefits are provided, having been working in Dell (Russia) for the past 2 years I'm still happy as I am, grew in knowledge a lot, salary is decent, health insurance, bonuses, over-time is paid in double. cons: No cons so far, guys!

cons: This is not about all leaders at Dell Technologies, as I had a few that were great and had a few that were equally horrible. However, Dell Technologies talks a great game about career growth and opportunities, but at the end of the day - smoke an mirrors. I worked for this company for 8 years and had to fight tooth and nail it seemed on a daily basis to been seen and be heard. Getting a promotion took an act of Congress. On the basis of loyalty - there is none. No matter how good you are or how much money you make for this company - it is never enough it seems. When times get tough, they will terminate your employment with no remorse. The only way to ensure you have longevity here is to make sure you are "in good" with more than just your direct supervisor.

review_title: Harassment/Discrimination/Dishonesty - Welcome to Dell OKC Sales!
pros: - High turnover so nobody cares if you leave. You shouldn't, either. - Easy parking.
cons: Ooh! What an awful slice of dated corporate hell this place is! I came in as a University Hire to the sales department, only once there, they had no positions to fill (after lying to us that they did for months), so after hooking us with a signing bonus, they put us doing cold calls 40 hours a week, with no chance at bonuses/commission or advancement. The SWAT sales people not in the University program get the same treatment, only no benefits and $15/hr. One guy had been there 10 months at this rate as they kept stringing him along to becoming a permanent employee, with no end in sight. "Culture" is a word used solely to discriminate against those who are unsatisfactory -- be it due to race, sexual orientation, age, or general intelligence/business sense. Qualifications and experience mean nothing in favor of a low-cut blouse during the forced "mentoring" sessions with the piggish (nearly all) male managers. As for the bonus structure, Google "Dell fraud" and you'll find the company has violated tax laws and misreported it's numbers for TEN QUARTERS STRAIGHT! The "numbers" they pay you on and expect you to hit are complete and absolute fiction. Avoid this place. The only people who succeed there are the ones who wouldn't anywhere else, which is why everyone you meet used to a be a "shopgirl" or "waiter" until working here. The (likely to be broken promise of) benefits got them hypnotized. This is not a good place to work for anyone with any actual earning potential. Since leaving, several hiring managers told me it was a good thing I left and it's actually a mark against you to have Dell on your resume in the tech world, as they have a reputation for not being able to fit in anywhere else. That fits, and since entering a position with decent management/transparency, I see what a truly negative and incompetently run experience this job truly was.

Cons
There are no cons that I have seen.

pros: The best thing about working at Dell is the on job learning. There isn’t a concept called bench... so you’re contributing immediately. The campus recruits- The ITDP’s as Dell calls them are put into a program that helps them transform into a tech leader. The face time you’d get with senior management being fresh out of college is something you’d appreciate.
cons: There aren’t much but given that Dell Technologies is a product based firm who are undergoing a massive transformation across their different business functions you might find yourself a bit caught up in the churn. Apart from that it’s pretty cool to be working with one of the biggest giants of the industry

review_title: Great Company and Culture for such a large company
pros: Was shocked at how much I enjoyed my time there, great leadership and there was a culture of improvement and doing business the right way. I was in the Sales Enablement (Product Marketing) side so I cannot speak to the Sales side but I love the entrepreneurial mentality that they allowed us to have there. Highly recommend the company and especially the Product Marketing side!
cons: As with all huge companies, politics does get in the way sometimes and also there is a lot of processes (good or bad) that you have to follow that slow down your daily tasks and of course there are meetings upon meetings upon meetings so you're often distracted from doing your job. That's what most large companies though...

pros: Very strong on Culture , Values & ethics. Thus it feels as a safe place to work at. Flexible work schedules
cons: Very large organization, multiple stakeholders , sometimes you can get lost.

review_title: Dell Technologies; an amazing organisation to grow professionally
pros: The management is amazing. There is ample opportunities and resources available to grow, plus the pay is very good. The culture is beautiful and people are very supportive.
cons: Honestly, None so far.

review_title: Okay company, competitive pay, but sluggish and high workload
pros: Competitive salary Training and career advancement opportunities Good benefits
cons: Super sluggish and non dynamic organization Bad work atmosphere due to new manager, used to be better Very heavy work load which can become repetitive at times

pros: Many product teams present, when any team or product does not interest anymore, changing to other product is very seamless Good work/life balance Nature of work purely depends on team/product Market leader in most of the product it sells, so good learning assured
cons: Appraisal cycle is very bad and confusing. It takes six months for hike to get effective after bonus announcement.

review_title: Wonderful platform to explore, experience and innovate world-class technologies
pros: - Dell product R&D (as in my example, Storage) has provided my the entrepreneurship experience with a safety net. Irrespective of country/region, you get to experience, learn and evolve and innovate technology leadership. - A fantastic Technical Career Path called the TLC. It provides an ideal platform with mentor-ship and opportunity to experience various technologies/external participation and most of all evolve and build technologies. Being some one who has been in this position in the past, I can certainly certify that TLC is the best in the industry. - Opportunity to easily interact with Senior management across the organization. - Be it a fresher or experienced, you get to choose what you want, own and deliver.
cons: - The organization keeps evolving and so unexpected org changes are very likely. Being adaptable is probably a requirement.

review_title: I work with very innovative engineers & the work is interesting but there is no growth.
pros: The local team is very professional and skilled. Its a joy to work with senior developers.
cons: There is a lot of inhouse training but it doesn't amount to advancement. Leaders are hired from the outside and brought in from their univ. friends.

review_title: Best work life balance. Recognize and reward is not great

review_title: Good benefits but popularity contest culture
pros: good benefits and I work at home. Free t shirts/swag. I feel like the sales goals are attainable. I have learned a lot about IT and computers from this job.
cons: I have never been promoted. Pay is bad because of lack of promotions. There are very little women who work there and even less that get promoted. In order to get promoted they tell you to work on your "brand" but what that means is to cozy up to the right people and drink with them, etc. Everything is a popularity contest. 1 woman for every 10 men. In management - 1/20. Don't ever engage the help of HR because retaliation happens all the time. If you don't hit your number, they don't care why. You will be out fast.

pros: fun perks - free food, vendors giving away stuff
cons: zero help for past employees - have not sent out W2s and it's february 18th have received 1095-c, but talking to anyone that is an actual person is impossible. about the job - i was hired as inside sales being told this is "inbound" sales, but when i got through training it was a bait and switch then being told i would be a "demand generation rep" in other words, i was cold calling. their only form of training is "dial more (not really but their training focused on selling and not their actual products) and you're constantly having to crawl over other employees who have already called the contacts you're given; i can not even begin to tell you how many times i've heard "someone else called me two days ago saying they were my point of contact, what is going on over there?!" you do NOT have set accounts you handle. people are snakes and will steal your sales and leads. people do not tag the customer profiles like you should, or there are 17 different accounts for each individual and someone tags a random obscure account, and you're both working the same account. they say "scrub scrub scrub" accounts but how are you supposed to be thorough when there are MULTIPLE accounts, using different phone numbers all for the same people. they need to clean up their accounts system. you are guilted out of taking PTO. while i was there, they offered over time but quickly rescinded that offer because people actually used it like they asked and expected beause nothing is better than SALES SALES SALES, so they offer over time only to then take it away beause people used it. i was at the nashville anniversary gathering for Dell, and it was weird that we were asked to scream and cheer for Michael Dell like he was some kind of God. he came out to an imagine dragons song to show that he was cool with the young guns.

review_title: I am working in Dell for 7.5 years now, Joined just after my B.Tech. as a DB tester then B.A. now Senior Finance Advisor
pros: 1. Salary is better compared to market standards. 2. Dell offers employees the chance to explore your career as per your interest. 3. Immense opportunity to train yourself from the huge library of training materials available. 4. Unethical practices are identified and punished. HR and Ethics team make it one of the best organization to work in. 5. Diversity at its finest. Dell gives chance to work in a global environment. 6. If you end up being in a team where the leader is not supportive of you or the entire team altogether, there is an opportunity to send individual feedback about your leader/s to an annual survey, conducted by 3rd Part Vendor. Serious actions are taken by the organization if the result of the survey indicates poor behavior from the leadership towards the team. So, unlike many other companies , here in Dell, leadership is serious about employee welfare.
cons: 1. Seat allocation system in Dell Bangalore is one of the worst and a process driven by EGO of the Dell Bangalore Facility Management . Dell does not have enough number of seats to allocate to all employees in Bangalore. There is no centralized portal/process for seat allocation. So, it depends on how good relationship your management have with the Bangalore Facilities higher management. Mostly it takes long time (sometime few years) for a new member to get allocated seats. So, privacy at work is a challenge. 2. The process of quantifying a non-sales employees contribution to organizational Goal is completely dependent on human(Manager) judgement. So, if a manager has personal grudge to one of the resource in the team, then that particular resource end up getting bad annual hike no matter how much contribution that person has given towards achieving organizational goal.

review_title: Excellent Company with the BEST people
pros: I've worked for several large companies and advertising agencies. I believe, without a doubt, Dell is the best company to work for. The people I work for and with are outstanding, genuine and looking for ways of helping everyone succeed. Not every day is roses, but to work for a company who is as focused in innovation and success as Dell is, allows everyone to be focused on the same goals. Most of Dell works remote 100% or at least 50%, this has made a huge impact on my work/life balance. I am able to work remotely at least 2-3 days a week. Excellent health and wellness benefits.
cons: I've heard from others that it's too big of a company/people get lost in the largeness. I think you chose your own adventure. If you want to be seen, make sure you are in front of leadership. Let your manager know that you are interested in other areas to grow in.

pros: Very friendly work environment and give massive opportunity to learn
cons: not to many to be honest.

pros: Overall compensation sets the standard for the industry. (And I have worked at other global technology company's). Benefits are generous. Company vision and strategy are solid. With the Dell Technologies company being an umbrella for several companies, there are lots of opportunities and paths for those who are career driven. My territory has really great senior management. The culture is very much on the side of business professional which I like. I have worked at another global tech company where the culture was more "hipster" and "disruptive: in their attitude and approaches and Dell Technologies definitely is not that. This could be seen as a pro or con for some, I have just found that the business professional approach is more successful for an organisation in their marketplace.
cons: Internal systems for doing your job are fragmented and unorganized. It took me over three months to get full access to systems I need to do my job. The Dell and EMC systems are not integrated yet. Processes in general take a while and can be kludge. Vacation time was something I could not negotiate coming here as part of my package. I have had four weeks of vacation for about ten years now and Dell Technologies starts everyone out with three weeks and they really emphasize that their week of shutdown during the week of Christmas is like having a fourth week of vacation. This may be OK for some, but for others like myself, I do not like being forced to use time off, especially during the week of Christmas which means traveling for personal time is less likely.

pros: Good pay and opportunity to move up
cons:
I don't have bad things to say about Dell

review_title: Not technical support, just a call centre
pros: Job is permanent, you get salary on time, plus a big name gets associated with you which can help in future jobs.
cons: Only good to work in Technical Support if you are jobless or homeless. Let me give you an eagle eye view, technical support engineer is just another "Call Center Agent" That is the reason technical support is paid pathetically less, outcome is extremely high turn over rate. Whole team is new every year, only hopeless guys stay. Dell is still a laptop company, even Enterprise team is handled the way laptop support is handled. Everything that matters is numbers KPIs, doesnt matter you know stuff or not. All the management knows nothing about Enterprise market outside Dell, all Managers have moved from laptop support to Enterprise management hence lack exposure of Enterprise world. If you come here in technical support, just remember, you are yet another head count, thats it. Poor office location makes the situation worse. When competitors have already moved towards Work From Home culture, Dell's technical support is still laid back.

pros: Good pay, good benefits, smart people to work with, technology leader.
cons: Dell Technologies the new name from resulting merger of Dell and EMC is a culture clash between two tech firms. Dell is a relaxed, telecommuting culture, take time off to recharge, closed for the Christmas holidays to spend time with family organization. EMC management wears as a badge of honor, how little vacation they take and expect you to do the same. If you are taking vacation you don't work hard. If you have to take vacation, take your phone and laptop with you. It's a "if your're not in the office to be seen you're not working" culture. EMC management scoffs at the idea a company would give employees time off for Christmas. No work life balance if you land in storage position. Look for a job on the server side of the business.

pros: Strong ethic company with good growth opportunities
cons: Poor leadership. Worse work-life balance

review_title: The politics at the upper echelons are horrific!
pros: The benefits continue to be quite worthwhile and I am glad to see that these have not been diluted. There are many pockets where leading-edge technology is being pursued but one will end up at one by dumb luck rather than career planning.
cons: Lack of information about what is going on, constant change to justify middle-management's effort to remain relevant in a changing market. We are told to adjust to change yet nothing changes beyond additional administrative/bureaucratic process changes. NO integration (only lip service) between Legacy Dell and Legacy EMC which makes career growth impossible. You cannot jump from one legacy organization to the other. As a result, there are a lot of yes-men in the organization.

Nothing will happen after that. - Managers overcommit with their superiors and then pressurize team member to deliver. - Can call person anytime to reply US mails. - No transparency in the process. - No one will take responsibility to give KT to new members. The intention would be just to save their positions by creating dependency. - Will feel biased environment within the team. Privileges for one member will be indiscipline for others. - Leads and Managers will suppress your idea with demotivating comments. - If you are planning for any certification or course then ready for a ton of questions. Intention's just not to grant the request.

pros: Work Life Balance is great, people are good to work with. Benefits are great.
cons: Discriminates against minorities. Been doing the job for over 4yrs and I have the same job title as my peers in all our regions, but they are one grade level above my current level. Everyone starting to notice the discrimination, I usually dismiss their comments as jest when they bring it up because I don't prescribe to it or think about it that much, but when a person has done the job for X yrs and someone comes in that has no management skills, or done anything for the company that is significant, but still gets the promotion it makes a person think about it deeper especially when it happens on 5 different occasions. What makes it worse, I have to clean up the promoted person's mess and it's clear the person has no business being a manager per peers and others within our Business Unit. I have been told by some peers that I should address this with HR, but I never wanted to be that GUY. By the way, this also happened one of my peers, guess what we had in common?!

employee_title: Account Manager: Global Client and Compute Solutions
review_title: Dell Technologies Review - specific towards GCCS
pros: When applying for jobs, I applied to more than most (upward 150 applications towards different jobs). With this being said, I was blessed enough to have multiple job offers. So why Dell? Personally, Dell stood out. The position, the culture, the pay, the benefits, the work/life balance, the people... it felt too good to be true. From day one, Dell as a company and the people that it employees have been nothing but welcoming to me. They have included me in and out of the office. They have helped me with any questions that I have had and done so with an amazing attitude. They have given me resources throughout Dell to help me get involved in other areas. For example, my manager knew that I loved to party plan and told me about our group "Winning Culture" that plans all of Dell's events. I joined the group and have loved every second of it. They have encouraged me, challenged me, and are helping to shape me into the business woman that I'm becoming. The people here GENUINELY care about you. There is so much room to grow and change positions throughout the company. If you accept a sales job here and realize sales isn't for you, no problem. Dell is completely comfortable and actually encourages their employees to bounce around throughout the company to discover what they really love. There is so much opportunity for horizontal (moving from one position to another in a different area of the company) and vertical promotions (moving from one position to a higher position in the same area of the company). I have absolutely nothing but great things to say about this place. As a recent college graduate and this being my first job, I know that doesn't really qualify me to know much about the workforce, but as far as I know, there is no place like Dell. If you ever get the opportunity to work for this company, please do yourself a favor and accept the job.
cons: I will let you know when I find them :)

pros: Great benefits and paid time off. If you’re lucky to have a good account set excelling and career growth is possible!
cons: Micro management. They would rather replace you with a kid straight out of college then pay you the higher level you earned. They provide cake quotas to newbies to prevent turnover while pushing tenured reps out the door with unattainable quotas. Truth is I made $25k more when I started as 2 levels below what I am now because management buried me in quota as I moved up. Upper management puts metrics on the reps that they have no clue of effect or backing to prove. If a team is leading in sales revenue, but lowest on call numbers they catch all holy hell that they need to make calls because that executive NEEDS to prove the calls metric leads to the sales they preached it would. If the forced metrics don’t meet what they preached it’s their job on the line so they threaten to make sure the numbers meet what they say works. You never know how your quota is created or given a fair and accurate picture of how it was. Management can load quota on different team members at their discretion. Somehow you grow your accounts 20% after a 12% quota increase, but you miss your quota by 25% match doesn’t add up... Management blocks upward movement if they don’t have heads to fill your current role. If you can get out of the sales seat and into a different role the company is amazing and job security increases 90%. Sales reps are expendable and not appreciated.

review_title: A solid culture within global operations
pros: IMO, the values of who you directly work will have the greatest impact on your job satisfaction. I've looked up to each of the leaders I've worked with - both for their technical skills as well as the leadership values they exemplify. The company financially is doing well and I believe has done so built on a culture of both hard-work (WHAT) and human-touch (HOW). Although not always transparent to non-managers, I've stayed b/c I believe and resonate well with the leadership values that are exhibited, especially when I see how they play out in our decision-making and impact the lives of my team members.
cons: At Dell, organizational change is fairly frequent (about every 2 years) and not everyone deals with that well. It is also still a very large company and so you will have to accept some lack of transparency at times in high-level decision-making.

pros: Your coworkers, very knowledgeable and supportive. Good benefits for health and dental. Bringing in best of class development tools and methodologies.
cons: Still going through organizational changes, restructuring groups, lot of consolidation. No stock incentives. Due to the change of development tools being used hard to establish a consistent process.

review_title: Transition from EMC to Dell was rough
pros: The transition from EMC to Dell after the merger was rough, but came with a few perks. The Dell employee discount is generous and funded two computers and a television while I was employed there. Training is generous and, at least while I was there, vouchers for certification exams were fairly easy to get, but only for Dell/EMC certifications unless you had a manager willing to do the extra work for, say, an AWS voucher. Work/Life balance largely depended on your client, not Dell. Dell by itself was pretty lenient about working from home as required, so long as you did not abuse the privilege.
cons: Being swallowed up by a much larger company squashed the career mobility of former EMC employees flat once the dust had settled. I wound up having to leave Dell to advance my career after two years of trying to move into a different position. Compensation was therefore also flat with little to no chance of change.

pros: The culture at Dell is a positive culture that posits that having happy employees will benefit the corporation. While the focus as at any company is on making revenue, that is a sense that while you can work as hard as you want to you should take time for yourself, the benefits are good and Dell favors working remotely.
cons: I don't have many cons, integration of EMC after the purchase is slow but that is to be expected. It is a large company and had a different culture.

pros: I have been with Dell Boomi for about 90 days and it has been the most pleasant and efficient on boarding and training process i have even experienced. (over 20 years in the IT industry). The management is attentive and available. Regardless of your area / expertise. Just to give you an idea of how much I believe in this company, I was a customer of theirs with an Investment Bank and switched careers to be part of this 'Boomi' journey.....
cons: Although the on boarding and training is already quite efficient, there is a lot of information available and at times it can be too much and seem somewhat overwhelming. But, once you get a moment to take a deep breath and compartmentalize it is easy to figure out what is next. I think it should be mentioned that the only 'con' I could document was the excessive amount of available information for on boarding and training. Not many companies can claim that!

pros: I found really professional the on-boarding process here. cons: One of the main reasons I´m not rating Dell with 5 star is the temperature at the office. It´s always freezing cold in here. I see every single week a colleague that has a flu or a cough . I have raised a ticket stating the importance of having a warmer environment, but the office is cold every single day. Another thing that I see is the integration between Dell and EMC. I can tell that there´s still some conflict. Dell has a strong culture on how to treat the employee with respect. I came across that this can be easily not follow. I´m sure that is just a matter of time to have a integration fully complete.

review_title: Great company for flexibility and stability
pros: Love the flexibility and work life balance. The ability to work 100% remote doing work you love is hard to find.
cons: Company runs real lean so don't expect to ever get a big increase in pay as you promote through roles.

pros: Good work environment and every member of staff was A1. Also a lot of training available to anyone who is willing to give it a try which is also handy for the CV. Rally enjoyed working here and work/life balance was superb.
cons: Company was more focused on promoting people for tenure rather than experience and ambition. Good company to see out your career or to get a good company behind you as a graduate but for anyone looking to move up the corporate ladder quickly I would aim to get out of this organisation within 2-3 years.

pros: Good learning curve, very rich in-house lab, knowledgeable trainers, good culture
cons: Pay less than industry standard, grouping among management, bad location

pros: With Dell Technologies being such a vast organisation I thought that I may be lost, and feel like a number within the organisation. The experience I've had couldn't be further from that. Starting with an informal buddy systems with a team member to the culture of getting things done, it's been a terrific experience. The training has been second to none and I've really enjoyed being an evangelist for the organisations within Dell Technologies. All the senior management have been brilliant too, getting involved in the on-boarding process to get you going as soon as possible with the backing of the business.
cons: So far, none. The standard new starter system set up wasn't an issue, which I was expecting.

review_title: A successful, supportive and diverse company
pros: I thought I had researched Dell Technologies well before I joined and was happy with what I had read but now I am onboard there are so many other positives that make me even more happy with my decision. Such as; Sixth year running Most Ethical company, this is very important to me in sales, selling the right way Employment diversity, all companies say it but Dell is doing it, females in senior and sales roles, many many ethnic backgrounds, again in senior and sales roles and a world leader in LGBTIQ+ employment. ALL of these groups and more having internal sharing and support groups. Dell doesn't just "do the right thing" they truly see that the company gains from a diverse workforce. My previous employer had a female on Reception and in HR and one Asian, made me sad and mad. Flexible work location initially had me a bit concerned around teaming but it actually works very well. The kit they provide you for home makes setting up a permanent home work environment very easy. My direct manager has a bi-weekly one on one to discuss me and not my deals. He and the company care greatly that employees are happy and supported. I have no hesitation in recommending Dell Technologies as an employer
cons: Sill finalizing the Dell-EMC integration which causes some frustration with internal systems and collaboration but it is getting better and there is a plan to complete the work.

review_title: Great Place to build a Career
pros: 1. Work ambiance is good 2. Excellent transport facility - 2 way cab round the clock 3. People seem to be friendly 4. IT team does excellent work in setting up a new employee with all the necessary things - Laptop , Docking station, Monitor , Bag , etc on DAY 1 itself 5. Flexibility to connect from Home (as required) 6. Provide voucher for internal technical certifications
cons: 1. Grade level provided for experience - Not satisfactory with the HR team 2. Onboarding process to team / Dell EMC product line - Not satisfactory as there is no streamlined way of handling new employees. Its mostly shadowing someone else's work (although this might be team / project specific) 3. Could do better in helping new employees understand the Dell EMC storage / DPS product line better

pros: I never expected to work for the same employer for 10 years, but this is the type of company where you can build a career. All of my roles have been interesting and challenging (I can't speak for everyone, but the opportunities are here). The Dell culture is welcoming and collaborative with many opportunities to mentor and to be mentored. I think that the company has come a long way in terms of its approach to and investment in innovation that will pay off for years to come. Although it's been said here many times, it's hard to beat a good work-life balance where you get to enjoy your vacation and have the opportunity to work remotely.
cons: Despite many lateral opportunities, myself and others are challenged to find more senior roles after Director. In some cases, people feel like there is a preference for external candidates over internal. It's not unusual for people to "boomerang" out of Dell to get the promotion/bump and then come back versus waiting for something internal.

review_title: Great Overall Stability and Potential But You May Need Patience
pros: - A stable job for a company that will be around for years to come - Build YOUR business - If you work hard to close and perform well, you will get paid well overall. - Pretty transparent about what you take home and where your commissions lie - Lots of room for growth - Plenty of benefits by being an employee - Feeling of family
cons: - If you have a bad territory, you're screwed. - Can be difficult to advance without over-performing (which is not necessarily a bad thing but worth mentioning the expectations) - High-octane environment where you need to wake up ready to bring it to really achieve. (again, not necessarily a bad thing, but it's worth noting) - Can have an air of "who do you know" to get ahead although it's not pervasive and definitely not indicative of all locations and positions. - Some in Senior Management are only concerned about themselves and their appearance. - Upper management can be very disconnected because they are not driven by the same metrics as sales so they put out numbers or goals that do not always align at all.

pros: You can work from home 2 days a week, IF, you hit your quota. Good Benefits. Good Vacation. Nice facility.

review_title: Great company when it was EMC, has been going downhill since Dell took over
pros: The TSE's I work with are great. When it was EMC benefits were better along with other things.
cons: --Managers don't care if you know something or not you are basically a warm body to take a case. --Very micromanaged environment with very little training for new people. --Top managers don't care about how changes affect the people down the chain. --All around it was much better to work here when it was EMC. Dell has been the worst and many people are leaving because of how bad it has gotten. --Managers follow upper management blindly and don't appear to care how it affects their people. Which causes low morale on the team --Since Dell took over benefits have a way higher deductible and seems like the insurance we have doesn't cover as much because people are always getting hit with a huge bill. --There is no clear career path, managers have no idea how a TSE can move up to the different TSE level positions

review_title: Fantastic culture, with ample opportunity to grow and learn
pros: Fantastic benefits, culture, and people. I've never interviewed at a company where people walk by and smile and say hello to a total stranger. I know that sounds like a small thing, but I think it goes to show you how happy people are that work here. It's extremely flexible in terms of work/ life balance. Management understands that everyone is an adult and that you can manage your own schedule - there is automatic trust that if you made it through the interview process, you can handle your day-to-day tasks. I love the 401k match, wellness options, and didn't opt into the health plan but have heard wonderful things. I will say that post-merger, it seems like the dynamic is changing - I am a fairly new employee, but my initial impressions of Dell being a slower, seasoned, traditional company are quickly falling to the wayside. People move fast and nimble here. I really love that, coupled with the flexibility.
cons: It's a large company, so if you're not used to rolling up your sleeves to get a question or issue addressed, this may not be the company for you. You have to sometimes dig and ask around a few times to get answers (which I enjoy, but not for everyone)

review_title: Only a good place to work if you've been there for a long time

cons: - 80% of the work is done by 20% of the people - Upper level executives are absolutely clueless and assign resources to teams that are better at marketing vs. teams that are actually solving engineering problems - Pay is below average - The environment is more or less an anything goes type environment. People can say and do whatever they want without any reprimand. I've seen things like managers making jokes about women's appearances, making fun of people because of their religion or age, and much more.

pros: The work environment is relax yet intense. We get to manage our own time and complete tasks at our pace. We are not required to spend 8-9 hours a day sitting in the office; instead we are allowed to work at home as long as we got our job done. Even though sometimes we have to work extra hours, but being able to work at home definitely makes me feel better. The managers are also very caring. They made sure your effort is recognized and spent time with you to help you understand the role you play in the team. Finally, DELL puts a lot of effort to encourage the employees to participate in volunteering works. This is not something I have seen in my previous job. I'm glad to have such opportunities to give back to the communities.
cons: Many co-workers are located in different countries so it's difficult to arrange meetings

pros: Gives time and importance to learn and develop products in new technologies.
cons: Extends till late as we research and develop.

pros: The Cherrywood campus is great, if a bit remote. Plenty of parking, with a gym nearby (though not subsidized). Great way to get your foot in the door of tech sales. Some truly great people work here. People always willing to lend a helping hand. Relaxed sales environment. Very lax attitude towards hitting targets and KPI's.
cons: Worst paying tech sales job in the whole of Dublin. I'm not exaggerating. Over half a decade there and my salary was worse than entry paying sales jobs in companies like Salesforce. Very little in the way of promotions, and salary increase. Horrific tools to do your job. I'll probably have nightmares about gii for years to come. CRM is a joke. So much rubbish and duplications that end up in internal fights with other departments and countries over account ownership. If you're too lazy to clean up the CRM yourself, at least outsource it to someone who can!!! Managers and above not interested in helping you develop your career at all. Actually, this is unfair, there are a few gems in this company, but as a collective, the drive is just not there. No free coffee or tea (petty complaint, but come on.. this is standard in nearly every office in Dublin). Canteen is really... not great. Revolving door of graduates. They constantly hire them because they're a cheap source of labour. While the company's founder has listed what the companies Values are on the website, there's absolutely no sense of follow through with them. Nobody cares. The only time they come up as a vague topic is during the dreaded annual ethics exam. Winning with integrity?? Yeah right. I've seen countless salespeople act and win business in unscrupulous ways many MANY times in Dell.

process, systems and support organization

review_title: a great place to find a retirement style career
pros: - plenty of work to do - variety of topics to engage on - vacation/pto compensation - appx 3 weeks for new hires - large company, lots of different teams and experiences to interact with
cons: - paperwork non-technical managers in highly technical engineering roles : You're on your own depending on team placement. - no mentorship programs / new-hire-integration plans for technical roles. Newly hired employees must find their own space and push their own needs forward. - work culture is partially locked in Waterfall, lots of old ideas from old-timers - endless bureaucracy and "not my job" attitudes baked into the work-culture (work hard play hard) - work schedule is not flexible as other employers, importance is placed on being visible and physically present at all times - take note if you have kids or family to attend to. Work from home is allowed typically once per month, but varies team to team. - dividing line between employees and managers, at times there is emphasis placed on one being above the other - we are not considered equals when it comes to asking for time to discuss project direction, team contributions, company objectives etc - very much focused on top-down employee direction

review_title: Great total compensation but old school management style
cons:
ltant in Austin, TX
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Benefits are great. Bonus structure is great, ranges from 8% to 15% to 25% (directors) to 40% for VPs and upwards... 401K is 6% match. Very good WFH solutions across the company, but that means early morning calls and late night calls to support global activities. Very solid in terms of business vision.
Cons
The leadership is very old white men's club. Even though they keep touting women in leadership , in reality, majority leaders by far are men, white and old timers. Very less chance for younger folks to go up the ladder. They are extremely cheap in terms of spending on "fun" stuff. E.g. no free coffee, no good offsite, no free stuff for employees. They only pay for customer engagement programs.

review_title: A full, honest review for candidates considering this position from somebody who succeeded
pros: - Money (Unlimited cap, lunches, spiffs) - Environment (Contests, playful environment, coworkers can be friends) -Big Company (Resources and career mobility) -Education (Strong marketable skillset despite where your next move is) I have been apart of three organizations, and I can say that Dell checks a lot of boxes. It is a great location, pay is very fair, and there is career growth so long as you hit your number and have good relationships with your peers and management. The skillset you develop will be very marketable (consultative selling, full-cycle closing, qualifying). This position will set you up for success, and you'll make a lot of money and have a lot of fun along the way.
cons: -Detached leadership -Unethical sales practices are celebrated -Quotas are dependent on other people The middle management is dangerously political with an unclear vision that directly impacts the morale of the floor. Since I've worked there, the culture has deteriorated. Quotas can be determined by favoritism. They are overhiring and the quality of hires have been declining. Management turns a blind eye to unethical work practices, and are in many instances rewarded because of the number they're able to hit with shady tactics.

pros: - Connected Workplace program to work from home - Very competitive salary/benefits/retirement - 12-week paid parental leave - Plenty of paid vacation/personal time off - Dell 401(k) 1:1 match up to 6% salary (max $7,500/year) - Great options for medical/dental coverage - Health/fitness perks
cons: - Not much... had to trade in my Macbook after Dell acquired EMC :) Luckily, they replaced it with a high-end Dell laptop.

review_title: Glossy facade, but problems beneath the surface
pros: Connected Workplace program gives workers flexibility in how they work - full and partial telecommuting, job sharing, etc Compensation seems competitive People stay with the company for a long time Affordable medical benefits
cons: Because so many people in my function have been with Dell for years, there is a lot taken for granted. Probably not unique to Dell; still, as a new hire, it's tough. It's like pulling teeth to get information and guidance, and I'm just referring to within my own team! Bit of bait and switch with my job - I was hired for my skills and experience in one area, and now I'm doing something quite different. Had I known then what I know now, I likely would have removed myself from the staffing process. I'm reasonably autonomous, but feel like I've been left to sink or swim in many ways. Conflict avoidant manager, so I'm having to figure out a lot on my own. I've had a number of payroll related issues, which leaves a terrible impression as a new hire. I'm a salaried exempt employee, been around since January, and my pay still isn't quite right. If I didn't need the benefits, I'd probably have resigned already. If I'm still around in 6-12 months, perhaps I'll feel differently.

review_title: Great People and lots of flexibility, but no real structure for new college graduates.
pros: - Lots of Flexibility around work hours, time off, etc. - Great friendly people who are understanding and genuinely willing to help. - Team Spirit: People show up to work to help one another -- there is no competitive tension among colleagues. - Managers and Senior Executives are intentional about investing in Diversity and Inclusion (D&I) initiatives; like in ERGs, attending D&I Conferences, etc. - Lots of online training platforms available for personal growth in non-technical areas like project management, etc. - Innovation: Simplified IP development process; engineering orgs promote innovative engineers - from all experience levels - to take on developing patents.
cons: - Not a lot of structure around new hires, no real "buddy" system in place to help new employees navigate their first couple months, especially college graduates. - Very minor bumps in salary for staying in the same role, not withstanding performance. One will need to change roles to see any significant salary bumps.

review_title: Emcee was a great place to work. Things fell apart one fell took over
pros: I have worked for EMC for over 20 years. The Egans were great to work for. They really cared about us and treated us great.
cons: Place really went downhill when Dell took over. My job title was lowered from principle tech to senior tech which cut my money. Also benefits were torn apart by Dell. Blue cross blue shield of Illinois is the worst insurance I have had in over 20 years. They do not pay for the same things the EMC policies we had with had under EMC. It was a nightmare dealing with our current insurance plan. Moral all around the company is very low. You sitting there worrying about layoffs instead of doing your job. It is almost impossible to get a promotion unless you know someone. Less quality people are always promoted overr quality people.

pros: Great benefits and overall culture
cons: Under paid for job involving a wide knowledge of products

review_title: Unfortunately there is a big difference before and after the EMC merge.
pros: - good co-workers from diverse backgrounds - there are good resources to learn from online - BUPA insurance is the best!!
cons: - Cost reduction is being applied to the maximum since the EMC merge. EMC was a really great place to work because the company focused A LOT about its people and invested in them so much whether in trainings or recognitions. However now Dell is changing all that gradually hoping no one will notice. Now their only focus is on numbers. - Trainings have been cut to the very minimum and almost all trainings are not approved now. - Recognition system has changed only to decrease the amount of money spent on it. it's been cut to almost 70%. - Even the annual raise percentages became a joke, really. They decreased the percentages and their reasons are beyond nonsense. Travel incentive has been changed and now they don't give you an incentive in your pocket but would just allow you to redeem 80-100 euros per day on food and transportation. So they stopped giving fixed pocket money as they did before. - Overall the culture changed. Even those they choose for management positions are no longer people-managers. They choose pure numbers-oriented managers. Turnovers have reached its maximum since EMC opened in Egypt. Everything changed and is going to change even more. - I never thought of wanting to ever leave the company when it was EMC but now, I would leave on first offer.

review_title: The job differed than what was presented initially
pros: Healthcare benefits, Garage Parking, working with other young people
cons: I was under paid by a lot. Management did NOT know what to do with their newly hired college grads. Some members of management behaved very rude, and the other higher uppers seemed to just tolerate that sort of poor behavior. I was presented the job offer as a business systems analyst but my role was not as one. I was placed as a healthcare consultant. It was broad name that covers consulting, call center, accounting, project management, and a few others. It was a weird time to get hired there during their a&m with NTTA Data. We were not made aware of this until the first day. I was given a hiring process packet to finish in two weeks as busy work and I completed it within days. After that, I sat around for months until I had my first project as a consultant. Shortly after, me and a few other newly hired college grads were laid off due to the a&m with NTT Data. Majority of my former coworkers in my age group are no longer working with Dell/ NTT Data

review_title: Great place to work, especially if raising a family
pros: Multicultural, lots of opportunities to advance, good compensation. If you get a good manager, they can really help you move up. For the most part, the "Dell Culture" of empowering employees isn't just words on paper, most managers are seriously committed to helping you be your best if you show the drive. Work/Life balance is amazing -- family leave policy is second-to-none.
cons: As with all large companies, the quality of your job will be highly dependent on your relationship with your manager. Very low effort is spent on "skilling up" employees(unless you're moving into management), other than some very limited "online training" resources.

cons: Because I Love This Company

review_title: Good place to work - fast paced and full of change.
pros: Competitive pay compared to similar companies in the same industry. Pension contribution. Fuel Card including personal use. Work from home policy including funding for home office & bills. Generous car allowance.
cons: The merger with EMC still has a bit of a hangover, with teams butting heads for power. This can cause confusion within the account teams and customers. Still very much feels like 2 separate companies trading with the same name. Compensation plans lead to "sell what's on the truck" behaviour. Can be demotivating having someone from the same company competing with you to ensure they get compensated.

pros: Great work life balance, employees are empowered for the most part to run their business the way they want provided they perform well & hit key metrics. Ability to work from home 2 days per week. Culture is FANTASTIC. Without a doubt one of the best jobs available in Oklahoma.
cons: The account set you get is luck of the draw until you've been there awhile and proven yourself - there are hard working reps who get bad account sets and don't make as much money as they should and there are terrible reps who just luck into high performing accounts. review_title: Virtustream at Dell - Hard work and little appreciation
pros: Ability to work from home.
cons: If you want a company that will work you to death, gives zero appreciation, small raises, and treat you terribly, this is the place for you. Virtustream is all over the place, they have way too much management and throw out senior director to anyone as long as they are completely incompetent and don't understand the product or operations at all. Public sector is an absolute train wreck and nightmare, upper management gives it no attention and the testing for the products that will run there are practically zero. The business tries to focus its talent and time into things that customers aren't asking for, they don't listen to you, and operations is horrendously anemic. Another main issue is that the company basically encourages bad employees, you work like crazy and another employee does almost nothing - good work team, carry on. You work an entire weekend, up till 4 am on Saturday, good job, pat on the back. 80 hours of work in a week might occasionally get you a $100 "reward" for you efforts, enjoy your $2 an hour of overtime. The company basically treats its employees terribly, my family has had to have an intervention with me. A previous coworker I worked with had a similar experience and was encouraged to quit for her health from being so stressed and exhausted.

review_title: Great start till a bitter departure
pros: Working here is a great entry point. You get in, learn a bunch, but don’t make it a lasting career. There are several good people to work with, and it can be fun.
cons: Management does not seem to care about your interest or future. Very little movement/promotions. Some people tend to have egos. Extreme lack of real training toward certifications. In support, you are more reading from a script with management breathing down your neck to get back in the queue. The politics are bad, the tools are constantly changing which is a big annoyance. Be warned, if you go elsewhere competitively and provide a 2 week notice, they will walk you out and you will not get paid the two weeks.

You'll always find someone smart that helps you - Very solid company - Most of the managers I had - in Brazil and US - were very competent in people management - Pluralsight trainings - Internal leadership trainings - Good amount of agile related trainings - Opportunity to work with people across the globe - I traveled to three continents based on project needs - Able to choose my career path based on my objectives and company support - Open doors with any team member, from a VP to any other peer across the globe - Quartely offsites - a day off with the team sponsored by the company - Recently with Eldorado move from PUC able to work from home once or twice a week.
cons: - Although the salary is fair, the other benefits are pretty basic - The Eldorado site sucks: * no windows * average food * transit may be caotic if you live in Porto Alegre - Although work and life balance improved last two years, a bad project can kill it. Had cases of huge overtimes including weekends. - Still very project oriented company - A lot of burocracy - Engineers have often work on paper work - Need pay more attention on software development practicies - Higher level roles require a lot of politics, even being technical - Brazil site lacks of strategic leadership positions on IT, making most important decisions be at HQ level - Some managers are not tech as they should.

review_title: Great place to work and have a good work/life balance. Not the most challenging place though.
pros: I worked in the server division as a firmware engineer. My management was great, hands-off, and very strongly supported their team members. The work/life balance was awesome in that management allowed you to have your own work style, hours, etc.. There were some very smart people here that are experts in their respective subject matters from whom you can learn a lot. There is a lot of career advancement possibilities here since there are many engineering titles. You definitely get recognized for your work if you make it visible and you will get rewarded for it. Personally, I was very happy with the team environment and the confidence of management to allow their engineers to make his/her own decisions.
cons: There are lot of people with a cruising mentality here. The bar for entry isn't the highest so you won't be surrounded by really smart people. The work is interesting and challenging at first but being a server company, you're not really working on the most cutting edge things. I'd classify Dell as a reactive company vs. an innovations company. There's not a lot of money is invested in R&D. I feel like while engineering has a big presence, the focus is more on making money in sales and marketing. I just didn't feel challenged enough and wasn't fulfilled with the problems that I was solving. There's not as many perks as compared to the tier 1 companies.
