review_title: Good if you are ok working autonomously then a ton of feedback
pros: Autonomy, collaboration, decent pay, work from home, latitude to make some decisions without a committee, creative outlet.
cons: Whikle automony was expected, review cycles did not come, even though people reviewing the content had seen the progress - positioning, messaging, concepts - along the cycle. Many time there was no a lot of time to incorporate feedback and back flips ensued to get things done prior to launch in a GTM setting. While doing the work leading up to the launch of a product/service/software, executives were regularly updated on messages, positioning, content, deliverables, etc. HOWEVER, not all execs. attended the meetings, there were too many people with input power and a thousand requests for inclusion of other offerings on the products that were sure to get attention. So it was a tough balancing act. It wasn't until everything - especially a press release where all the aforementioned information was on two pages, was there a visceral reaction. So then come the back flips - to hurry up an change any of the above where translations were already done and paid for...and would have to wait a quarter. Also, sometimes when you had the decision, there were internal fights over the decisions and groups, like development would hold the schedule hostage until one bent to their way of seeing things. HOURS WASTED. Finally, in all the cost cutting that went on, many groups would layoff or reassign people in an organization - let's say Online (responsible for the process and general design of webpages) - to show they were within their target cos-cutting. It looks great on paper, BUT the jobs that were vacated generally rolled up to the marketing manager who already had their hands full with photography, videos, content, brochures, aligning organizations, staying within brand guidelines, coordinating with the communications team, providing feedback on press relases, often time representing Dell at events or press briefings and getting all that coordinated by specific dates for translations, legal review and ultimately launch dates. So then there would be more added to the plate in addition to all the reviews with executives.

pros: The company has a great work/life balance and is embracing the new remote work lifestyle which is great. There is a lot of opportunity for new challenges, if you speak up and your manager approves. Health & wellness benefits are great.
cons: Company culture as a whole is not innovative, very set in it's old ways and incredibly risk-averse. It is difficult to do anything outside of the set path, and risk-taking is highly discouraged. The onboarding process for new hires is fragmented and abysmal, people dont have laptops or passwords. Culture can change varying by team but it seems there is a general attitude of "not my problem". Compensation and raises are capped at a very low percentage compared to other tech companies, even for high performers.

pros: The benefits and time off is wonderful. If you can actually take time off.
cons: Let’s just say it’s a call center. You will not be able to leave your desk except for two fifteen minute breaks and lunch will sometimes be 1 hour but a lot of times it will be 30 minutes. If you get stuck on a PIP plan, start looking for a different job because you will not get off it and you will be let go. This is a job you stay in for about a year then run as fast as you can. You will not get good hours after quarter 1. You will be micromanaged in everything from your time on the phone to how long you go to the bathroom. Would I work in this job again maybe if I was desperate but it’s not worth the headache and low pay.

pros: Tons of opportunity and upward mobility. The company has returned focus to providing quality products over the past year, support has greatly improved, and the company has done a great job innovating.
cons: Merger has chased away/downsized great leaders and individual contributors. As a result, the leadership quality has declined, and the manager to employee ratio out out of line. Dell has tried to commoditize the entire EMC portfolio, which has led to a counterproductive field sales clash, and led to a big shift away from an enabled sales force that understands the value of Dell EMC solutions and how they work together. Instead solutions are regarded as products, and likened to the same selling motion of a laptop. It's evident in the decline of field sales enablement and the removal of training opportunities. There are still Dell sales people incentivized to sell products that compete with Dell's own products.

pros: The salary and benefits are pretty good. There's also an actually decent focus on work/life balance. Aside from the occasional long hours before/during a release to production most people pretty much keep it to 40 hours/week. Most people also have flexibility to work from home at least part of the time.
cons: To put it nicely, on the whole I would say that Dell (or at least the engineering space) is a giant, inefficient, incredibly frustrating organizational mess. When the company went private several years ago a good chunk of the best engineering talent either quit or were laid off. Since then the direction from management seems to have been to outsource about 2/3 of all team members to India and to never get rid of under-performing employees. So over time as many of the great engineers are promoted up or leave the company out of frustration we've seen a steady degradation of overall quality on software teams. There's also a frustrating amount of red tape to go through for every little thing. Want to deploy a bug fix to a test environment that will unblock several downstream teams for next week's release? Gotta wait until the end of the day when deployments are unlocked for 2 hours or else get a email sign-offs from 5 managers who don't know anything about your project, several of which may be asleep on the other side of the world. Lastly, over the years I've seen management change hands and departments renamed so many times that I literally don't even pay attention anymore if it doesn't directly impact my team. And especially when upper management is changing around, there's a good chance somebody somewhere is getting laid off. Makes people nervous. So to kind of sum up my pros and cons here, if you want a relatively stable job with good pay and benefits, decent work/life balance and flexible hours, and you don't mind dealing with a whole lot of frustrating nonsense tangential to your actual work then Dell might be a good fit. But if you're a real go-getter and want an exciting environment to work in then I'd suggest looking elsewhere.

review_title: Great pay and benefits, but too many changes from the executive team
pros: Awesome healthcare packages; wonderful 401K match; best college reimbursement I've seen; excellent employee work groups (supporting veterans, LGBT community, associates where English is a second language, and many more); They provide an on-site small gym, open 24/7; They offer an on-site cafeteria, but only during normal weekly business hours; They are heavily involved with the Utah corporate games; And they do contribute and encourage a lot of employee involvement in charity work (i.e. Utah food bank, habitat for humanity, STEM groups for kids, and volunteering at IT and STEM events around the Utah valley).
cons: Executive leadership at Dell is extremely frustrating. They make top down decisions about everything and leave managers constantly struggling to explain and keep up with changes (with zero employee or local management feedback). The only issue with their healthcare package is for married couples, where the spouse has a full time job at another company. Dell EMC actually penalizes these employees, basically making it more affordable to just drop your spouses Dell EMC coverage. One frustrating thing at Dell EMC is employee growth opportunities. They constantly have an extremely high turn over rate because people find it easier to leave and come back in order to get more money and/or promotions. And the final thing that was most frustrating to me personally with Dell (not EMC), was the employee purchase program for Dell products. They provide an annual 17% discount, which is nice, but that 17% is based on the retail price of the products. They would really increase their own employee purchasing and using their own brand if they provide a better program where employees could purchase Dell equipment for around cost.

Also, some of this minority from the management team doesn't really understand about Anxiety Stress and Depression Situation and they just fire you, as It happened to me, no taking in consideration that I subscribed in the program that Dell offer for this kind of issue. This kind of things (minority people) are the only few cons from Dell. I worked at Dell Panamá, also some of then who stays in a comfort zone in their position and due this, some times we are unable to have career opportunities inside the business unit

candidate and employee experience team
Thank you for reviewing us. We appreciate your time

pros: Benefits are cheap, all around the people you work with are nice, good PTO.
cons: The technical sales rep job is a literal nightmare. I came to Dell for the vast opportunities it boasted. Unfortunately...those's opportunities are seemingly at the very end of a long, dark tunnel. During the interview, I was very hesitant about the sales position. I had read pages of pros and cons regarding Dell and addressed them in the interview. I was told those reviewers were liars. Still, against my better judgement, accepted the position as I was told, "if you end up not liking the sales position there are thousands of other positions!" The 9 weeks of training were very informative, fun, and filled with the Dell koolaide but didn't shed a ton of light on the day to day of the job, which now I understand why. If you enjoy: micromanagement being told you'll lose your job if you don't make the sale cold calling people begging for their business Being lied to about your commissions Weekly change of your quota and metrics then this job is perfect for you. I find myself either bored to tears or stressed to tears with no in-between. The turnover here is incredibly high. I've already started prospecting for another job. Why you ask since there are so many opportunities? HA well, you are forced to stay in your position for 18 months and it's virtually impossible to move out of the sales rolls as all these ridiculous metrics they put on you are impossible to obtain. AWESOME. Also beware....when you do decide to look for another job, if you leave Dell within 2 years you have to pay them back your supposed 3 month guarantee of $5,000 (another thing they boast in the onboarding that doesn't exist) This place is sketchy, corrupt, and a living anxiety attack. Seriously - do your research. really think about it before you sign the papers. there are so many better opportunities out there.

pros: I can't think of anything positive to say

Heck massive company, overlapping roles, unclear direction, was "promised" by hiring mgr my focused area, only to see him move to another internal position 3 months into my new job. He was replaced by someone outside the company..

review_title: Best Company I worked for so far...

review_title: The most Toxic company in the valley
pros: Nothing I can think of.
cons: Where to start? Politics – Totally passive aggressive. Everyone is pretending to be your friend all the while they are trying to stab you in the back to get ahead. Head of departments avoid confrontation at all costs. How do you rise to a VP or SVP without dealing with confrontation? Lying is expected and encouraged here. This gets funny because they forget which lie they tell to who and routinely get caught and laugh it off. They won’t outright fire someone, scared to so they pick at people until they’ve had enough and quit. Collective IQ – This is the dumbest company I’ve ever worked for, they give new meaning to the Peter Principle. Now don’t get me wrong, there are smart people here but on a whole, the smart people can’t raise the collective IQ. Everyone is waiting for their green card to exit this company. Petty – Had to go over to see it myself. They have management in another building that counts disposable cups and complains that too many are being used. They have posted signs on the coffee machine that only people that work in his group or visitors can have drinks or snacks. Benefits – Worst benefits in the valley, full stop, real third world stuff. They had a “Tell Dell” survey last year and benefits came out as something major for the company. In the end the only change they made was reducing the company matching 401K and benefits stayed the same. When I started, I had to bring in proof that my kids were indeed mine. People having to pay out of pocket for routine test that at every other company I’ve work at were covered, things like blood tests, x-rays etc. are not covered. Don’t get me started on their “health screening and wellness”, employees signed their health history away for ~$600 or two months out of paycheck contribution, now they have people’s health history, god knows what they’re planning to do with it. BTW, if you’re a fan of drug testing, then Dell has something waiting for you. IT – Absolutely nothing works, their systems, their laptops and/or desktops. They force an operating system that resembles Windows and everything is locked down, access to outside internet resources, applications, everything, still didn’t stop wide spread virus problems from hitting the company. Their hardware is the worst, someone in another builds laptop almost started on fire in his bag on the way home. Machines routinely reboot for no reason and ports are disabled. They have an application for every function. There are literally hundreds of applications that you have to use for PTO, Benefits etc. and most only work through IE6. You have to get permission to have admin rights on your machine but still can’t do anything. They made a change to accessing email, forcing everyone to windows and outlook, this left the Linux engineering community out in the cold. All meetings run through Skype which barely works. It normally takes 5 – 10 minutes to get a meeting started because of Skype issues. Travel – There isn’t a published process on travel other than to be cheap (except if you’re an executive). I know someone that had a medical issue that had to travel and after a doctor’s excuse and weeks of process hurtles, they got a dispensation to travel in business internationality. This was scrutinized by management and called into question every time they were required to travel. Reports on “exceptions” are reviewed by the division heads quarterly and you don’t want to be on that report. Tell Dell – They tell you that the internal survey is anonymous, yet you have to put in your userid. You give them honest feedback and they know where it came from. HR here for their own good. The have HR reps for every function and they are all over the country. The routinely skip the people they are working for, manufacture problems and go to the division heads so they can look good. One of the heads of HR would not meet with employees until they submitted questions in writing. When they didn’t get enough, the person cancelled meeting with employees because he was afraid of what they might ask him. Have and Have nots: Sr directors and above get perks, travel in business, paid phones, special laptops and other perks setting up a class system in the company. And just in case, micro management is also king here, to get an expense report or anything completed it needs to involve at least 4 – 5 layers of management reminiscent of a 1950’s manufacturing culture. Bottomline here – I could go on but let’s leave it at, this is the most toxic company I’ve ever seen in the valley.

review_title: Technical Support Engineer III/Advisor at DellEMC
pros: There are many training and development opportunities. Perks aren't impressive and seem to be gradually getting worse since Dell acquisition, but benefits are good and floor+regional level managers really do seem to have employee needs strongly in mind. Personally, I have found that initiative and hard work is rewarded and recognition is regular. There are financial rewards available for stand-out contributions as well. DellEMC has a great entry level program with good starting pay for new Technical Support Engineers. Emphasis on mentorship and coaching for new-ish (up to years in some departments) is one of the most positive aspects of building a career at Dell.
cons: EMC seems to lag a good way behind the market in pay and it's not improved after Dell bought EMC => DellEMC now. I wouldn't call it bad, but workplace perks and efforts to raise employee morale/satisfaction isn't on the same level as most of the surrounding peer companies, including the large tech corporations in the area. Unfortunately, Dell (including DellEMC) does seem to be the type of big tech corporation that only compensates you fairly as you enter the company and doesn't do much to identify and hold on to superior employees. It's pretty standard that TSEs in these kinds of companies only stay for 2-3 years before they're being paid well under market value and move to another company to make any real progress (think 3%/year if you stay vs. staying 2-3 years then moving to another company with a 20% raise... even moving back a couple of years later for matching pay if you want).

pros: It is employment, kinda sorta.
cons: The stories you’ve heard are true, it’s a modern day sweatshop. They are hopelessly understaffed, and intentionally so, because it saves them money. They will heap a simply impossible amount of work upon you. You will find yourself spending your entire workday wandering from pointless meeting to pointless meeting. During each conference, you will have several hours of work assigned to you, with no time to actually perform the assigned tasks. At the end of the day, management will simply tell you to “get it done for tomorrow”. The implication being that you’re supposed to get out of work, and then go back to work - from home during the evening. I regularly get email from my coworkers around 3:00 AM because they’re still up at that hour doing the work that they were assigned during the day. They come in to work exhausted the next morning, looking like death warmed over, because they were up working all night and got no sleep. It is common for management to dump 20+ hours of work onto your lap at 4:00 PM on Friday afternoon and order you to have it completed for Monday morning - so much for your weekend. Needless to say, there will be no time for vacations. Just work, work, and more work. What kind of a life is this? I’ve seen young kids in their early 20’s need to be on medication just so they can cope with their jobs. It will eventually catch up to you and make you sick. When that happens, you become a liability. It would expose the company to further liability if they were to terminate you because they made you sick, so instead they will try to torture you into quitting on your own. They will double down when you are on the verge of collapsing and heap even more work upon you. They will write falsely negative performance reviews and otherwise make you so miserable that you just can’t stand it anymore. If you refuse to quit, you will simply be eliminated in their next round of contrived layoffs, which are pretty much constantly ongoing. Then they will bring in a fresh piece of meat to replace you and work them to death next. I have never seen such an incredible rate of turnover. They should install a revolving door on the front of the building, oh wait, they did! Seriously, the rate of sickness and heart attacks is shocking, several people have even died. It all boils down to one word: EXPLOITATION. Maximum exploitation of everything and everyone that they come into contact with. I have never seen such a Marxist commodification of human beings. During my orientation, the HR rep actually said “We are the Borg. You will be assimilated. Resistance is futile.” (look up the science fiction reference if you’re not familiar with Star Trek). They went on to tell us that “EMC stands for ‘Eventually Marriage Counseling’ because of all the long hours that we are going to make you work”. They might as well say “welcome to the company, we’re going to ruin your marriage”. Honestly, they actually said these things to us during our orientation! They expect you to put the company before all else in your life. It is supposed to come before your home, your family, your relationships, your happiness and even your health. This loyalty and dedication will not be returned though, in fact, they will screw you in a heartbeat if it saves them a nickel. Virtue is a vice at this place and they are an inhuman calculating machine that operates completely without a conscience. Their employees mean absolutely nothing to them and “corporate ethics” truly is a contradiction in terms here. There is a striking lack of policy regarding the treatment of workers, and a striking lack of enforcement for what little policy there is. They will berate you, humiliate you, belittle you, insult you and torture you. Coercion is basically the only form of motivation that they know. If your manager wants to put a gun to your head in order to extract an additional 3% output, well that’s just fine with the executives – in fact, it’s commendable. They basically let managers do whatever they want. And you know what they say about absolute power… HR is complicit in the corruption. When management wants to screw you, it is HR’s function to basically “grease the skids” and see that it is done in such a way that does not expose the company to liability. They are experts in re-writing history, deception, underhanded behavior, dishonesty and getting around the law. It's like something out of the dark ages. You are not going to get a chance to tell your side of the story, you will simply be ambushed on your way into work on some random day. It’s every dirty trick in the book, and several more that they have invented on their own. Every argument is one-sided and they’ve basically discovered that dictatorship is a very efficient form of government. As a condition of being hired, you are forced to sign the most onerous and draconian document that I have ever seen. It includes such conditions as allowing the company to access your private email accounts and waiving your right to sue. That’s right, you must give up your 7th Amendment rights and agree to resolve any disputes through their arbitration process. I can just imagine what kind of justice you will get from the company court. Just why do you think they’re doing this? Every relationship is adversarial, rather than cooperative. Management against workers, groups against other groups, workers against each other. Once management realizes that you don’t trust them anymore, they will approach you through someone that you do trust (usually a colleague) and screw you through them. You will eventually arrive at the accurate conclusion that you can’t trust anyone. This culture is completely toxic, but they ridiculously try to sell it as “excellence”. Incompetent people are constantly promoted to senior level positions, while exceptional workers are trapped in menial jobs. It gets to the point where titles don’t mean anything at all. They would much rather hire cheap workers than talented ones. They especially prefer foreigners or young kids who can be tricked into performing multiple people’s jobs and working 80 hours per week for low pay. Key contributors are regularly eliminated because management basically figures that they have already extracted most of what they’re going to get out of them. Politics is king and the old boy network truly runs the place. Working here is like being trapped in a spider’s web: the more you try to struggle, the more entangled you'll become, and it will eventually kill you. Ultimately, it’s just best to stay away from this place.

review_title: Avoid this place at all costs!
pros: Adequate pay, but absolutely not worth it.
cons: They are literally working people to the point of sickness and death. Had to attend my coworker's funeral after he died of a heart attack brought on by work related stress at the young age of 38. He left a wife and children behind. Know of several others that died under similar circumstances here. The ambulance carries people out of this meat grinder on a regular basis. Almost funny when the rescue truck parks directly under their "Great Place To Work" banner (it should read: "Arbeit Macht Frei"). Their regular and unjustified layoffs are used as purges to eliminate those who can't be legally terminated. Once they make you sick, they see you as a liability to them and you will be ambushed at the next layoff, which is never very far away. In a blatant effort to remove anonymity from their employee satisfaction survey, management actually exported a copy of the survey onto an external website and forced us all to take it there, before submitting the real one - just so they knew exactly who said what about them. Imagine this: people are literally dropping dead around you and you're supposed to say what a wonderful job management is doing, or you will be laid off. Never have gotten a raise and have never even been paid my full salary in all the years I've been here. You will be forced to carry the workload of 6 or 8 different positions combined into one job. Everyone here is miserable and management has got "railroading" innocent people down to a science. Backstabbing, incompetence, corruption and politics are all rampant. The best thing you can do at this place is to leave. Haven't seen people treated this way outside of a concentration camp!

cons: Minimal opportunity for promotions. Dell has a “try and buy” culture for talent, many times making a person perform the responsibilities of the title above them for more than a year before promoting them, if ever. Having worked at multiple , large companies, this is not standard. If the person is doing the job, they should get the pay and title associated with that scope.

review_title: Horrible place for immigrants and lacks teeth in technology
pros: Absolutely none, Nill, how can I fill 5 good words!!!
cons: Age old technology. Senior engineers take decisions on how APIs should look and junior engineers code it out. This model is so flawed that nobody takes complete responsibility for a component. Those who design APIs keep reworking because they lack the insights into implementation details and those who fill in the APIs have little idea of how it applies across components. Legal team is a big let down and yet the company supports it with max trust. They have messed up so many of the employees through faulty applications, untimely filings, illogical suggestions, and so on. They are totally incompetent and they walk unchecked, unaccountable for any glorious blunders that they do. I have personally seen more than a dozen of my H1B colleagues leave this organization just for immigration purposes. More are in line!! My advice: If you are on H1B, stay away from this place. Being in bay-area and not have RSUs is like the biggest joke. Once Dell took over EMC, all RSUs were taken away and most of us are left with 50% of TC. Only a small fraction of employees are getting long-term incentives and that's been thrown like biscuits to dogs in the range of 5K-10K for 4 years vesting. Even people at VP level discuss on issues as small as why this API is looking this way and managers hold meetings all day to go through gory details of several components without having a clue of what they do and how they perform. Managers are zero quipped with technical ability and yet they work day and night on technical decisions. By the way, this cry is all about DataDomain.

cons: Doesn't pay as well as a lot of the big software companies in Seattle. Also, lots of bureaucracy, red tape, layers of management. Dell EMC is actively trying to dissolve the culture of the smaller companies it has acquired. My team is good, but I wouldn't recommend anybody work here as a software engineer because odds are, it will be on a team which isn't as good as other companies to work at. Also no sexual harassment training of any kind which is shocking. In the grand scheme of all white-collar jobs out there, it's still great. But in terms of West-coast software engineering, you can do better.

review_title: Great place to work for mothers!
pros: I'm working at Dell since 2010 and even after returning back from maternity leave (where I've stayed almost 3 years) I've returned to the same job. I could work part-time in the beginning and if the little one is sick I can work from home. This is the flexibility Dell offers me. My work-life balance is great and there are plenty of other benefits too. I love my job at Dell :)
cons: It is a huge corporate, so it's not suited for everybody. There are processes you have to follow and even if you don't like them you have to bear with them.

review_title: Huge improvements over last few years, but not quite there
pros: - Lots of opportunities internally and Dell is only going to grow. - Time off: 3 weeks vacation, 2 weeks PBA, 2 weeks corporate holidays. - High performers are rewarded with numerous LTIs. - Granted patents pay a significant LTI - Work-Life balance is good. Working from home is encouraged within reason. - Great culture. You are measured by your effort and not the color of your skin or religious alignment. - Healthy Living Lifestyle cuts the cost of insurance significantly per year, per person.
cons: - Hard to get fired, which means that every team has dead weight. - Flat title structure. It is extremely difficult to get promoted. - Bonus structure is tied to entire companies performance. i.e., if Storage does bad, all 100k+ employees get less of a bonus. - Health insurance could be better (Aetna).

review_title: EMC is now DELL. Yes, accept that and you could have a good time!!
pros: Good number of leaves (20 vacations, 10 public holidays, 12 sick leaves, 12 casual leaves) with leave encashment. Good technology in the teams I know. Could turn in to a retail and enterprise hardware-software giant if the management's vision works out. Opportunity to move around in the company through internal job movement every 18 months. Helps you build exposure to different teams, products while providing a good hike. You will need to go through interviews again for the new role. EMC is Market Leader in its domain. EMC is Known brand in market. Dell is a known brand in homes too. Work life balance is very good in my team. Good managers who treat you fairly with respect in my team.
cons: I was part of EMC which was acquired by Dell. Many employee friendly policies from EMC has been removed. For example - insurance cover (reduced cover, added copay, removed parents cover), advance loans, higher study programs, variable pay payout times - all removed. Feels like our benefits have been taken away. Cost cutting everywhere to pay for the huge loans Dell had to take to pay for EMC. Effects almost all areas including team outings, travel, goodies. One of the worst performance and appraisal cycles I have seen. Performance cycle is Jan to Dec. Appraisal happens in OCT next year. i.e, 10 months after performance cycle ends. Neutral feeling on the way goals and inputs are captured. Rarely see HR around. EMC is being brought in to Dell culture - way of working, policies, pay and benefits etc. Working style, software development methodology etc followed in my team was much better than the current Dell way of doing things which we are being asked to follow. It is still good if you are joining from a service organization. For anyone coming from another good product organization, the benefits and working style will not look good. Almost all the old EMC senior management has moved on. Its a Dell company now.

pros: • Successful at luring new young employees in thinking they’re going to get the “EMC” experience. False! That no longer exists; which is fine if the business model improved after M&A, but it has declined significantly.
cons: • M&A between Dell & EMC still in the process after almost 2 years, systems still not synced making it extremely difficult to perform ones job at a high level. • Disconnect between upper management and employees. Communication almost non-existent. • IT support horrible! Being told something simple can’t be done, then having to “YouTube” how to DIY. • No longer local HR on-site; only HR available is in Dell HQ [Austin, TX], or online chat...who then directs you to speak to local HR, which is not there [?] • False advertisement of “enjoyable engaged culture”...ice cream socials, LIFT committees, DO NOT equate to people being heard, it’s just a smoke screen. * not a disgruntled employee, just anonymously stating the truth! *

pros: The name brand and location
cons: DELL EMC (Draper): Heavily micromanaged and feels more like a sweatshop than a modern company. The only employees who can benefit are the managers who never change because they want to keep their positions. They only hire managers from outside the company so never dream of progressing while working there. Expect to work as a contractor for at least 2 years before they convert you to full time. The pay is below industry standard for the jobs they have. $16/hour to start and they may raise you up to $20 maximum after several years. You can find much better jobs in the valley that pay more than $20 and they provide you with benefits and you are full time from the get go. They use very old software technolgies and provide you with at least 6 tools to use instead of 1 centralized ERP that makes your life easier. They hold you responsible for any tiney maual mistake you do and act like jerks. Team members think they're managers and there is lots of conflict. You only get 2 15 minute breaks and you need to tell all your co workers when you go to the bathroom. You want my advise skip anything that says Dell EMC.

pros: This company offers amazing benefits that start on day 1. They have the best 401k match, time off, and culture for the sales force than I have ever experienced before.
cons: Dell doesn't pay commission based on straight dollar amounts. They used blended buckets of different products for an averaged attainment.

review_title: Road within the company to become a Senior Technical Content Developer
pros: - Allow you to work from home or the office. You can choose to become a fully remote worker or balance your time as you see fit. - Support new hires, and give you as much time as you need to set up your benefits, handle HR/IT needs, and go through the required orientation/training steps. - Create documents covering a wide spectrum of technical topics, from complex topics pertaining to software/hardware engineering to guides intended for day to day use by the supply chain and manufacturing. - Focused on fostering a team atmosphere through work related and extracurricular activities.
cons: - Worked for the company in a lower position, which led to an opportunity to mentor with the Senior Technical Writer supporting my group. Although I was lucky enough to find someone experienced with mentoring young writers, it was an upward battle for support to grow in a direction indirectly related to my day to day job.

review_title: Great place to work - springboard your career
pros: Great atmosphere at the Bratislava office, very friendly co-workers. Opportunities to grow were always present if you are willing to work hard (even rotations to different departments). Flexible working hours depending on your manager and team. Home office possible and encouraged by senior management. Bratislava site building offers gym, canteen, café.
cons: Salary wasn't the most competitive for supply chain jobs (at least from what I heard among foreign companies), but that has also to do with the local market. Jobs that have been moved from western countries see lower salaries than their counterparts. Job grade levels and salaries are constantly pushed down or people are not replaced to save money, which can be a disheartening for the employees who stay, but that is quite common in big companies I believe. To grow within the company you often need to accept responsibilities of a higher-grade role before receiving adequate compensation and promotion, which can affect your work/life balance, but the opportunities are there if you are willing to work hard.

pros: # Great Top Management # Clear Vision,Purpose & Strategy # Culture Code # Good Work/Life Balance # Lot of internal competitions to win Dell Goods/Awards (Innovation is really encouraged across the company) # Easy to reach out to top management, and they will surely reach out to you at least with a THANK YOU note. # Top management always lookout for feedback from team members, and will take actions if something is not working properly. # Lot of opportunities to collaborate with other teams (even internationally) # Work from Home # Lot of community engagement activities, you can be part of.
cons: # No opportunity to learn additional courses, since managers are too much concerned about their budget. They are not concerned about their team members career aspirations, they will tell they support your aspiration. But they won't do anything! Managers are concerned about their job and target, not about your career. Their goals are our goals, you are not allowed to write your aspirations in the annual goal sheet. # Monotonous work, which definitely won't help you to grow. # Moving internal is very tough, even though you got experience/qualifications. # Mid-level managers doesn't encourage communicating with top management, even though leaders encourage it always. # Difficult to get visibility from managers, if your team is big. Hence forced to look for job outside the organization, even if you like the organization. # Ongoing Cost controlling/cutting initiatives. (Whatever I mentioned is related to my experience, mostly related to my department)

pros: Big company means more security than startup.
cons: Compensation and Benefits not really competitive in Seattle area No real upward technical path, need to move to management to make any real career advancement once you been there 5 years. Company makes noise about mentoring, bulding your techncial chops, etc., but that doesn't happen here.

review_title: The Dell CULTure is infecting a great thing
pros: Very smart people to work with Encourages work-from-home For those who travel, a decently liberal travel policy Decent work/life balance
cons: Dell CULTure is infecting the EMC culture. Given that EMC itself had a strange culture, it was still a company people loved, both employees and, clearly, enterprise customers. With the Dell merger it is all going in a terribly wrong direction because the Dell CULTure is truly an infection that'll take a gold standard enterprise company and turn it into the "race-to-the-bottom" box slinger, like Dell has always been. Also, it is very clear the debt is taking a toll on the company, so it creates an uneasy atmosphere.

review_title: Dell is a Great Place to Work
pros: Dell has a great culture of networking, you are able to reach out to anyone and set up time to chat. They strive to be #1 in every business and shows by the investments they make and the money they are willing to spend to be the best. It's great working for a company that strives for that.
cons: The onboarding wasn't as well developed for non-University hires and I didn't feel I received the best overview of Dell upon arrival. But, over time I have been able to go to trainings and gain that knowledge.

pros: Dubai is tax free, but this is not so much a pro for Dell EMC but for Dubai.
cons: HR are utterly incompetent, they told me on my last day after I moved out of my house that I needed to stay an additional week to cancel my visa cause "I didn't resign in the correct manner". This would result in my possible detention if returning to the UAE. They refused to honour my contract and eventually stopped responding to emails all together. As a transfer from the UK I was advised that nothing would change transferring to UAE, but this was a complete lie, pay rises were promised and never materialized, and I was travelling 95% of the time. I drove my car one time in 45 days, promises of less travel also never materialized. The toxic Dell culture seems to be taking root in EMC and its all down hill. Most of my colleagues are looking to jump ship from conversations I have had for similar reasons.

review_title: If you get acquired by Dell, leave
pros: Flexible work/life. Every employee is golden, because the attrition rate skyrocketed, and they don't hire replacements.
cons: Pay is not competitive. Office is empty. No interesting work. No innovation. No raises, good luck EVER seeing a promotion. Corporate propaganda emails read like they were written by a robot, then filtered through 17 layers of HR filtering. They promise change. It's been more then a year. There is no change. Took a promising company with a big profit margin that employees loved - and "melded" it with a bunch of under-performing companies, then proceeded to cut our budget to the bare bone. That's why there's no raises, no good pay, no innovation.

pros: -It was an honor to work for Michael Dell. -Great vision and strategy from executive management. -Decent Benefits and great 401K -Good money when you over achieve....but you will be capped. -Generally good corp culture....even though there are tons of slackers.
cons: -Territories shrink, customers are taken away, quota keeps going up. -Standard OTE is low for industry. When you over achieve, they try to get you closer to OTE. -Capped commissions. -Mid level management lacks any courage. Manage by spreadsheets and are not true leaders. -Negotiate the best salary you can. You will not get a raise and promotions are rare. -Need to keep reinventing yourself and move to different positions. You can perform yourself out of a job. -Constant customer satisfaction issues due to product quality and solutions engineering. -30%+ of your time will be spent on administrative tasks and meetings. Constant fire drills. -Getting people to do their job is like pulling teeth. Lots of corp slackers. -Very poor work/life balance. -Not bleeding edge technology. Dell always seems a bit behind.

pros: Global company and brand. flexible working
cons: I worked in Legal. Seemed to be a culture of blame when things went wrong instead of collaboratively trying to fix things. People constantly throwing each other under the bus, which created an atmosphere of fear that causes people not to speak up. I have never in my life seen such inefficient and confusing processes. I think that the people are generally very smart and talented, and care greatly about what they do. However, they are too busy competing and trying to prove each other wrong, rather than working together for the betterment of the department. Time is greatly wasted on preparing for and attending an overabundance of meaningless internal meetings instead of actually getting real work done.

pros: After two years I can say that joining Dell has been a great experience. I have an enormous amount of flexibility when it comes to doing my job. The compensation is fair and on par if not better than competitors and peers. I am able to balance my personal and professional life. There are a lot of rewards and benefits to be had if you know where to look.
cons: You will need to advocate for yourself and learn to maximize the benefits and rewards that are available to you. There is not a lot of hand holding and finding mentors might be a concern for some. Onboarding is more of a sink or swim experience. Being proactive and open to learning will be a must in order to succeed. If you struggle with those things, you might face some challenges and frustrations.

cons: - It's a large company, unless you're proactive about driving your career and professional needs, you can feel neglected and unheard - It's a profit-making organisation, so performance is measured - When you're new, it takes about a year to learn the ropes, due to the size and diversity of the organisation

review_title: Frustrating experience as Software Engineer on the "transformation team
pros: Good pay for the effort of work. Very laid back work place. I probably work 25 hours a week and spend the rest of the week learning.
cons: As a software company Dell is unable to innovate because IT department heads are always fighting each other. In the time I've been here I've seen new ideas and innovation squashed by micro managers and inter-departmental disputes. Managers tend to protect their friends and have normalized a very aggressive, non-collaborative behavior. There is an enormous drive to make the boss happy so work is constantly being re-prioritized to meet the whims of "leadership" Overall pathological organizational culture. Almost no one can offer or take constructive feedback because any honesty would spoil their reputation among their peers. Interpersonal issues that could be avoided by a little honesty and feedback often degrade into overtly heated arguments or passive aggressive scheming. I've personally witnessed at least 3 of my co-workers throw each other under the bus to "get ahead."

ohocken, PA
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Good Pay Good Products Good Support Overall good working environment with the tools to be successful
Cons
They have conditioned the customers to buy at the end of the month or the end of the quarter to get the great deals. Executives come to town and give away deep discounts to close deals that otherwise may close in near term. If the customer doesn't have the ability to buy at the end of the month / quarter for any number of reasons the pressure tactics can create a deal breaker. Reps will dump accounts that they did a "one and done" see you in 3 yrs end of quarter deals leaving the quota and the account clean up / possible broken promises for the new guy. The sales jobs are good for 2.5-4 years. The guys that last longer have a few good established accounts that continue to produce.

pros: Impressive gamut of technologies at DELLEMC that are the leaders in their respective fields [for the most part]. Very competitive pay, opportunities for advancement. Flexible schedule and decent opportunities for advancement. A lot of training available and flexibility to choose how you spend many days. I liked to take 4 hours once a week for some dedicated time for developing a knew skill. Good benefits, tuition reimbursement, etc…
cons: Company culture in Utah seemed exclusive from my perspective, I found it difficult to get along with colleagues in a casual setting. Highly competitive with no clear indicators for success. Likely related to the High attrition in management. Nearly two years since the acquisition by Dell and there are still several redundancies that duplicate workload related to the knowledge base, Code Base, CRM, HR, AR/AP. Inequality among employees with regards to responsibility, and almost zero accountability among support staff.

pros: Salary and benefits were decent.
cons: Lot of favoritism. Doesn't matter if you are top performer or on a long term project you will be laid off. The more you butter up your manager the better probability you can survive. If you are on visa stay far away from this company. They laid off mostly everyone who were on visa on residency and asked them to move to the partner with same salary but meager benefits, no 401k and no expenses. They will try to manipulate you and won't pay any severance and pressure you to accept partner position because you are on a visa .

review_title: Good work but company management needs a rething
pros: -Really good work -Latest Technology
cons: -Too many management changes - Company direction not clear

pros: Went through a phase where it stepped out of its legacy process and incubated or acquired some data storage software for modern environments. Lot of success during that phase as well as some innovation. Was able to attract and retain some top notch engineers during this phase. If you are good, you got to work on some interesting distributed systems problems. Unfortunately this phase ended with Dell merger.
cons: After Dell, the team I was on, was essentially wrecked. Hiring freeze and no attempt to retain best talent meant all good engineers left. Tried to make up by aggressive hiring in cheaper countries but those teams couldn't cope and project quality took a deep dive. No development of new features - all the time spend on trouble shooting. Obsessed with sales but lost customer goodwill due to declining product quality.

review_title: TSE II position (after going through GSAP training)
pros: --Excellent benefits --Great opportunity to advance certifications (all MC certs are free) --Great opportunity to work with/on advanced technologies
cons: --Coming in as a GSAP employee means that when your two year obligation is over, you will be significantly behind the salary curve for peers in other companies. pros: There are a lot of good folks at the company. The pay is decent and benefits are still good compared to the rest of the industry. You can find work life balance , very flexible about working from home , time off. At this point probably a really good place to start a career in the industry but don't stay to long..
cons: The social culture of Dell is very cookie cutter corporate america. Some of that had permeated into EMC but Dell seems to impose a lot more of it along with hours of superfluous online training - I don't go to work to be socially engineered - I go there to make money. I expect a certain amount of required training on corporate policies but its a bit heavy. More importantly it is obvious innovation is a thing of the past at this company. They keep up with the rest of the industry and do a great job at maintaining what will become the legacy of the industry. In other words, the downward spiral that often happens to excessively large companies is starting. I suspect they are headed down the path of many of the companies that were once great.

review_title: Was a great place to work...once
pros: Paid Christmas shutdown week, work from home options, great people, on-site gym and cafeteria
cons: The fear of layoffs is a constant at Dell EMC now. What used to be a once-a-year thing, now is a year-round constant process. Since Dell acquired EMC, there's been a lot of changes. A lot more documenting and reporting. Benefits seem to get worse and worse by the year (we used to have 6+ options for health plans, now we have 2 - HSA and a not-so-great PPO), a working spouse penalty (not sure it's even legal). A lot was promised, but all we see is tons of layoffs and benefit cuts.

review_title: Good benefits and pay with remote work options
cons:
ltant 
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Pay and benefits are good. Corporate Incentive Bonus is a big plus, not just words, as Dell pays ever year some better than others but much better than any other company I have been with. Depending on your role there are remote work options. Other great benefits around employee wellness and discounts. The Dell employee purchase program can really save you some money.
Cons
Large company that goes through a lot of changes. You will get shuffled around a lot to new groups and managers. I am on my 6th director in 5 1/2 years. Working hours can be long and a lot of siloed work for customers, so not lot of team involvement. Career growth can be limited depending on the group you are in and you may have to seek out an internal move to be able to move up.

review_title: Great Place To Start and Finish
pros: Really great job out of college. It's 100% who you know. amazing benefits. amazing people. Management is really understanding. work from home is t/th. Just work hard and be sure to mingle with managers and other workers on the floor.
cons: They say it's a meritocracy, but you absolutely need to know who to talk to and who to know in order to advance.

review_title: Do not work in the support organization
pros: good benefits and that is about it
cons: It is as every past Dell employee will tell you, Good place to start, not a place to stay longer then a year or two. They believe in Low pay and high turnover, and will burn you out until you cant take it Currently the employee morale is at an all time low in the support department. 30min lunches for the last month and no end in sight. Low pay Dont invest in employees Low Morale No room for advancement

review_title: Started off well under EMC, but the wheels fell off after the Dell acquisition/merger.
pros: Company does/did allow employees to chase knowledge, learning and certifications. It’s a huge company, and is a leader because of its size.
cons: Everything is being moved offshore. There is no loyalty from the company, especially since the Dell acquisition. There are always work force reductions going on now, and there is very little strategy around why. Dell finance now controls everything, and will make poor decisions that can flip a project from profitable to negative overnight, with no impact on them but all the impact passed on to delivery teams. Messaging from leadership is spotty and tries to obscure the truth. Everything that was promised during the merger has been put to the wayside, and benefits have slowly gotten worse. Cost cutting is everything, even when it negatively impacts employees and clients.

review_title: Executives Change Direction Like The Hill Country Winds
pros: Once you're Dell-badged, there really are great medical, dental, and vision benefits, plus a corporate matched 401k and corporate matched funds for qualifying charitable contributions, which you can have deducted from your paycheck. The time off after 5 years with the company in the US is 4 paid weeks of vacation plus 2 weeks of personal/sick time off as well. Until recently, the work/life balance score would have rated as a pro, too, since Dell was finally catching up on letting its employees work remotely so as not to be tethered to a cubicle in a hot Central Texas office for a job that can be done over Skype and email from anywhere. Alas. . .
cons: It seems that each year the executive leadership in charge of IT either abdicate and flee or they get pitched some new & improved methodology or business model that requires a major upheaval of the existing organizations and interrupts the in-flight projects being worked under last year's buzzworthy methodology. Next year, some enterprising young consultant will probably show them a time- and money-saving new method involving three-toed sloths embedded in the on-site teams, and the execs will fly in dozens of sloths to try and make that model work. When they do, I hope they post lots of videos, because sloths are ridiculously adorable, even from a corporate hell hole that's lost all empathy for its employees.

pros: When I started in 2011, salaries were competitive and it was still run like a typical company - some bureaucracy, reorgs that seemed to do nothing, but staffed well enough to accomplish most of our goals if we worked hard.
cons: Cost savings killed it as a place to work. They brought in workers from offshore to replace US staff,, understaffed our area, provided just enough support to not to lose contract with client - but nowhere near enough to keep client happy. Reorganized so usual departments - like HR - became managed services and were pretty much unavailable. I had an employee who needed to be on short term disability and it took me several workdays worth of calls/emails/hanging out on hold to get information on how she could apply for it. Staffing became a nightmare because they insisted we go through specific vendors that provided low-quality resumes via unworkable web portals. Overall an unbelievably miserable experience.

review_title: Not for the faint of heart
pros: Average pay Access to manager for 1:1 and development
cons: Continual yearly re-organization never allows processes to settle before upheaval Ruthless pursuit of profit over people, despite claiming people are #1 asset Politically charged environment

pros: Salary. Benefits. Flexibility for working from home.
cons: After VCE was acquired by EMC which in turn was acquired by Dell we've witnessed - and are still witnessing - what Dell calls 'harmonization' of roles, processes, benefits, salaries and procedures. Instead of harmonization they should have called 'vandalizing' or 'thrashing' or 'defacing' or 'destruction'. Development of products that were successful for years has been stopped. Successful Account Managers have been prevented from seeing their clients with the result that the relationship that they had formed throughout the years has been completely disregarded for the advantage of the Account Managers closer to the Dell leadership. Processes that had been working for years have been scrapped and replaced by 'standard' processes that make sense for one organisation, not all of them. Organizations that have been successful have been forced to work in different ways, with the obvious result of mass exodus of talent that had been in the company for years. We have been force fed meeting and twits and presentations and cons call about how brilliant and seamless the merge has been. Well, really? no. So, if you are planning to work for this company make sure in the interview you ask the right questions, because this has become a massive, awkward, clumsy, bulky corporate environment where individualism is a swear word.

review_title: Great people, limited by blind senior management
pros: Atmosphere, benefits, opportunities to grow, flexibility, appropriate tools and working conditions.
cons: First of all 1-month training is a complete disaster - most things you learn there are not related to your everyday job. Almost everything you need to learn by yourself when you are already "on the floor". Fortunately teammates are very helpful. However because of inappropriate training and onboarding there is a huge rotation because newhires resign after first 2 months. Second problem - as an entry level employee or even manager you mean nothing at this department. Procedures and processes are prepared by people who have no idea how your work looks like. If you want to report that somethings is wrong, they will punish you by giving you additional work and if you resist they will find some reason to give you peformance improvement plan so you stay quiet.

review_title: Over a decade at Dell Services / Consulting / Professional Services
cons:
lting / Professional Services
2 Dec 2017 - Senior Technical Consultant 
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Overall Dell is a meritocracy and if you can produce you will be rewarded. The people are fair, good and generally work hard. Other pros include: * Encouraged to do the right thing for the customer * Everything is above board and straightforward including sales * Customers tend to follow the straightforward honest work of Dell itself * Teams tend to exist for long periods of time without a lot of churn meaning that the teams are strong. In other words your immediate teammates will be there and work with you. * Dell is very serious about the Tell Dell annual survey which is an opportunity for the rank and file to give feedback to all levels of the organization in an anonymous fashion. I've seen this correct problems with 'challenging managers' and bad teams. Dell is focused on keeping it's people.
Cons
There are still merger activities going on between Dell and EMC creating a little bit of instability between the different units. In general this is smooth, but sometimes it creates conflicts between different units. Another con is career development. In the early days it was pretty easy, as Dell grew promotion generally comes via lateral transitions to opposite teams. This can be considered a pro as well in that once in a role, it tends to be pretty stable without a lot of immediate team churn.

review_title: Legacy EMC member watches in disgust
pros: There's nothing positive about my review.
cons: I'm a Legacy EMC employee for over 10 years, and I absolutely loved our company. Ever since Dell acquired our company it's been nothing but down sizing and financial constraints. They are ruining our once great company, and I expect most of what was EMC will be gone within the next few years. Ruining lives, and wasting money. That's Dell's motto.

review_title: Health Plan Costs Increase Astronomically for 2018 - over 300%
pros: Great team environment with verbal recognition
cons: New Benefit package for 2018 came out, and I wondered why the web ex over emphasized how great it was - now we know - health benefits (even for an HSA plan!) went up 300%. To try and compare apples to apples, you have to call 8 different numbers - 1 for next years enrollment, 1 for this years enrollment and costs to date, 1 for FSA for this year, 1 for FSA next year, and so on...benefit helpline is useless. 4 carrier changes in 4 years, and you are on your own with comparing the benefit options and costs for each one. Comp plans penalize for high performance, and because the company is so large, it is next to impossible to address inequities and implement logical changes.

review_title: Lots of Room to Grow, but Compartmentalized
pros: Various departments to transfer to and learn new products, fairly straightforward pay scale, most managers will help you succeed.
cons: Too many silos of very specific products, especially higher in tech support, very little ability to become well-rounded. Techs coming out may be crippled in the "real" IT world at first.

review_title: Great place to work, stable environment, & capable management.
cons:
stent, transparent and earnest management. Annual 360 reviews of *all* staff contributes to openness to improve. Company culture is: -very positive and nurturing. -inclusive and fair. Long term careers at Dell are viable (currently). Management teams receive good training and are professional through out. Meritocratic progression/culture as far as it can be seen.
Cons
Silo mentality in some departments which leads to frustrating "inertia" (hence only 4 stars). Translates into perception of "indecision" when actually, people are working frantically in the background, simply trying to get people to engage in a 130,000+ company. Cross org collaboration is already on Mgmt radar, but difficult to change due to sheer volume of work. Opportunities to move into different areas that are not directly related to your vertical isn't so easy (but management teams are aware of this - remedial activities limited to within BU at the moment). Although my recruitment process was actually very good, others I've met haven't had such a great experience. This doesn't reflect the core capability of Dell UK, who generally aim to do their best and are very capable. Not the top in terms of salary, but good training resources (training every quarter) and initiative to manage your own time - micro-managing doesn't happen, which is great.

review_title: Was good as EMC, now just ok as Dell-EMC
pros: I worked at EMC for over eight years before we merged with Dell. I enjoyed the culture and liked working there.
cons: Leading up to the Dell merger, it was all about the numbers. No one really cared about the customer in the end. They just wanted to save money.

pros: They have good technology, good engineers but not good managers. Reasonably good salary and office is situated at good location. Specially in some business units, low level engineers are good compared to some senior level engineers.
cons: Managers want work done and quality doesn't matter. They lack technical skills. Shows lot of favor-ism for promotions and salary hikes. Due to this, some senior guys are stick to the company for long time and getting good perks irrespective of their work. Some Principle engineers who are there for long time, doesn't even help new joiners. On top that they do not even know how to code. They are surviving because they are pets to managers. You always find them with managers (for coffee, lunch, etc..) than helping other in the project. At the end, they show case other's work as if they have done everything under guidance of managers. I haven't seen any one gave good technical presentation or given good inputs or written code especially in the BU which I have worked. Some principle engineers always tries to avoid technical discussions that shows how impotent they are. But such people are white-collars there for nothing. Managers doesn't have sporting spirit in reaction for managerial reviews. Rather they target engineers during appraisals, layoffs etc.. Layoffs are there every month and only survival point is you should be a pet to your manager. It was not the case earlier. Some QA mangers are far better than development manager in some groups. This company has worst HR team and doesn't address to employee comments specially of low level engineers. Layoff are very common here. Work is moved under maintenance mode so not much development in some BUs.

pros: I can speak from a engineer's point of view: -There are many challenging and diverse projects to work on. cons: There are downsides of being such a large company, though this is unavoidable to a certain extent: -Decisions and direction can take long time. This can be frustrating. -Cube farm environment.

review_title: Really depends on your project and manager
pros: Supportive team members, nice place to work for people who wants stable life.
cons: I've been on two teams at Dell and had experiences with two totally different types of managements. While working on the same product and giving good amount of effort for both teams, I got recognized well from the first manager, but was told that I was not working by my second manager while I worked till late nights every working day. When I have only worked for 9 months on the team, I was shown by the manager the amount of work of colleagues that has done over 2 years, and told that I was not doing the same amount of work! I was given minimum amount of training before put on project without choice, and was switched around to work on things that were not even within my field.

CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Dynamic environment with opportunities to grow.
Cons
The meager with Dell is a cultural collision. The EMC way was successful and aimed at a top down approach of bag the big target and not to worry about the crumbs. All in all, it is a paycheck and would not recommend this as a place of employment. In addition, the benefits are below even the newest startups or respected Valley operators standards

pros: Good benefits. Flexibility to work from home. Great team at the ground level. Great collaborators on the teams I interacted with cross-functionally. Basically, a great place to work at the individual level and one or two managerial levels above. I worked for the Isilon Storage Division. The people I worked with are/were passionate and quality-focused. They built great relationships with other teams as well.
cons: Isilon was acquired by EMC and then EMC merged with Dell. Prior to the Dell acquisition, our team was cited as an example for other teams to model and our content strategies were adopted by other teams. After the Dell merger it became clear that our contributions were no longer understood or valued. I was laid off by someone who maybe knew my name and salary. My direct manager wasn't consulted in advance. I can't recommend working for a company that makes decisions based on criteria that's unrelated to skills, contributions, value, and knowledge of the product. No job security here, regardless of the quality of your work.

pros: Michael Dell as the CEO Great Vision for growing and maintaining leadership position Always going above an beyond for our customers
cons: Too many products to focus on Support organization needs to expand

pros: In the small business segment they definitely teach you as much as they can in training, so it's not a problem if you've never been in sales or don't know how computers work. Depending on the team your on (inbound or outbound) the KPI's are pretty reasonable. Unlimited overtime, uncapped commission, lots of "competition" money available that's not considered part of your quoted pay or benefits, TONS of free food (like some weeks I never had to buy or bring lunch) KPI's are predictable, and if you're not hitting those they have a good track record for performance improvement plans. Lots of people go on PIPs and end up having great numbers in the months afterward. Great opportunity to learn more about technology from both a hardware and software perspective AND once you're in the Dell network it's much easier to transfer to another department or position that you might find more attractive.
cons: Working in the small business segment is a little bit like working in a frat house. The reps are rowdy and whiny. While there are a number of more middle aged employees (people of all ages work on this floor), they tend to hire a lot of young people and recent grads which I think attributes to some of the rowdiness. There are so many "incentives" to sell that people end of coddled and throw a fit if they don't immediately get the gift card they won or the free lunch they were promised before. Things can change at the drop of a hat. I had an emergency and took a Friday off and when I came in Monday I had a new desk and a new manager. KPI's are predictable, but management will be really slack one week then bring the hammer down the next week (like firing people for not hitting very specific numbers). This pressures the reps to do some shady things. Sometimes management turns a blind eye to these things, especially if it's "technically" within the bounds of what's allowed. To give them credit, I have seen reps fired for doing unethical things, and one of the company's core values "Winning with Integrity" does come up a lot when people start mentioning those shady practices. Work life balance is difficult. Putting in longer hours to learn more about the product and processes definitely helps in the beginning, and then even more so when longer hours mean more talk time with more customers. But obviously this is difficult if you have kids. People get promoted based on good numbers and tenure. While I believe those both matter, a poor salesperson might actually make a good coach, and a good salesperson might make a terrible coach. I've heard of manager's not getting promoted to positions they deserved because they were 1 month outside the required tenure. That's a technicality and shouldn't matter if the person is skilled (which they were). There's also this growing schism between what they practice and what they preach. Training was like this fairytale land where you could be good at your job and grow into the position with integrity. When you hit the floor it's like every man for himself and you do whatever you can to sell more. At times the manager's will encourage you do what you were trained on, and at other times they say the only things that matter are what you're.

review_title: Sales success is becoming more difficult
pros: Good benefits (401K, dental, medical, HSA, etc.) Training is good. Work-life balance is great if you have the guts to stick to it (most people fall for the carrot). Pay is between 36,000 and 60,000 (regardless of education or technical background). Just sell.
cons: Sales management is weak (high school diploma or college drop-outs). They have favorites when it comes to promotions and assigning territory (which determines how your career progresses or ends). Sales quota is challenging. People with tenure haven't got a raise for years now (as of August 2017). Unhealthy internal competition due to different incentive plans for team members.

cons: The Tell Dell survey, gives opportunity to a very immature crowd to put your opinion which might not be correct

cons: I uprooted my whole life for Dell and was let go in 2012. I haven't been able to find a job that comes close. pros: Dell has an excellent work life balance. They also offer lots of opportunity. For such a large organization that went through a massive merger, they move pretty quickly.
cons: I hear a lot about the go to market and strategic vision, but at times if feels pretty rigid and not very adaptable to smaller businesses.

review_title: Great company but some weak middle management
pros: Company has a lot of great technology and in many areas they the leading products and services. From the endpoint to the cloud. The channel network is getting mature. People are incented to attend or follow online trainings on a weekly basis. Employees are provided with a good overview of what is going on in ICT. Employees are rewarded with a good salary and additional rewards. Ethical business is key. Most managers and contributors have a great drive and a positive attitude.
cons: The annual reviews and 360 reviews used by some as a mere political instrument. A limited number of middle managers are too busy with politics. There is a lot of uncertainty on the result of the merger with EMC.

pros: Dell offers a flexible schedule that allows you to work in the office or remotely. There is also a work life balance
cons: Depending on what department you are in there can be restructuring every six months. New teams are created and some dissolved.

review_title: Dell is a Great Company to Work For
pros: Work-Life balance, work from home benefits, flexibility with moving around roles, room to promote, everyone you work with is helpful and want to see you succeed, feels a little like a college campus sometimes with the happy hours and work outings, rewarding atmosphere and great culture
cons: Most people work more than the standard 40 hour work week, you need to be extremely driven and well organized or you will not succeed since you are doing a large amount of self-managing, the quoting/ordering tools/processes are constantly improving but they still have a lot of room for improvement, getting a promotion is not as easy of process a process as it may seem (have to pass a yearly "license to sell" exam over the products, need to hit your quota consecutively, need to prove yourself all the time and write up a personal review twice a year).

pros: Job duties Facilities Job Security

Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
The experience you gain while working for a company of this size is fantastic. Many opportunities to work with cross functional teams and gain visibility into new areas of technology and business.
Cons
Unfortunately the current culture is losing its focus on Consulting Services. Historically Dell has jettisoned its Consulting business at different points through the years. Given the recent acquisition of EMC, and the changes in senior leadership specifically within the Consulting Services organization, I don't believe Services will remain a high strategic priority from a corporate perspective.

review_title: Fast Paced, High Energy, Thrive or Die
pros: EMC = Everything Must Change. It was invigorating to work for a company where new products, partners, events, ideas, concepts, strategies were constantly being generated to meet the next wave of technological change. I worked here for 5 years and absolutely loved the opportunity to work with collaborative and smart people interested in diving into new concepts to make a difference for this $25B company around the globe. Having a family of 60,000 people in every state and most major cities around the planet was inspiring and fun. ....of course that also means late night or early morning conference calls.
cons: Can be a political company, definitely need to be careful about being authentic and transparent. Use caution as politics surrounds the organization. Challenging to move up, grow as a leader and gain the opportunity to manage others though internal transitions. Many managers are hired from the outside.

review_title: All depends on who your manager is...
pros: --Incredibly intelligent coworkers. All hard working and for the most part willing to help. I have made some lifelong friends with this company --Growth opportunities are endless. They encourage you to be open and honest about what type of positions you'd like to explore and your manager will (hopefully) help you in obtaining that next step --WFH flexibility --401k match --Fast-paced with interesting projects always in the pipeline
cons: Sadly, most of the pros quickly dwindle if you get stuck with the wrong manager. I have had some of the best managers of my life here, and some of the worst that leave me stress ridden. "Mean girls" mentality basically sums it up. If you are unfortunate enough to have this happen to you, run, don't walk, to another job. It really is sad. Work life balance is a pro and con...meaning yes, WFH flexibility, however, you'll more than likely be working so much it's difficult to find time to get away.
