pros: I worked for the GETS Enterprise Storage delivery in Canada for almost 5 years. What a great team. Tom L, Deo P and Neetin were the best managers and team leads I've ever worked with. I'd certainly recommend working with this team to anyone who loves storage and enterprise systems.
cons: Internal systems need some work. Concur has issues meshing with corporate cards.

review_title: Was better than OK at first but everything started doing down hill years of change
pros: I cant say much about the pros as I started hating the job due to many changes with the management and support teams being to district with the way it was being ran there own way. Perhaps the bonuses and gifts were probably the best things. In regards to gifts, they would give out like a $50 amazon gift card if you were performing well or something even better, or even time off from the queue for as long as 2 hours and still get paid.
cons: Required approval from team leads or management on EVERY part that was to be sent out for replacement on each clients computers. Had to go by a stupid form to trouble shoot a problem that you already know how to trouble shoot, they literally had to see the form results pasted in the notes on each call that we got. Team leads that were hired 6 months from the role I started, running the show there way, example would be that if you didn't go by the form that you were supposed to follow, they will put you in a one on one with them in a room and had to explain why we're not following that form. If it continues, you had to sit with the team leads and the manager and threaten you with verbal warnings. Also we had to open a case for every call that we take, and take ownership of that case until fully resolving there issue. There were more than many instances where we needed to get off the inbound calls, and take outbound time to make those calls to the customers we owned, but we're denied because of the queue being so slammed, and then we would get in trouble by the management as to why we haven't been touching our cases EVERY DAY! Little did they realize they never gave us the time to do so, it was like slaving in there. Another thing is that they are always hiring, you would see a group of 20+ people every 2-3 months take a training class, after almost 2 month of training and start taking calls on the floor. Possibly about 65-80% of those people that was hired had left Dell within a time frame of 1-3 months after there training as it was just to complicated for them with the way this business is running.

pros: If you are one of those people who is concerned only with making descent money, has no life, and no desire to have any kind of personal life - than this is the job for you! If you're fond of S1 pages all day/night long and you don't require more than 2-4 hours of sleep a day (or every few days sometimes), then this job is for you! If you're a workaholic insomniac with no family, friends or life and you enjoy high stress and regular management intimidation - this is your job baby! Lets sign you up!
cons: There is Absolutely no work life balance for their SAM's. None! It's a sweat shop that will consume every minute you allow them. You had better be prepared to prioritize the job over every aspect of your life, because that's what it will take. Its also doubtful that hard work and dedication will take you far within the company - better learn to play the politics or you wont last a year.

My manager has had multiple complaints about her from vendors and other co-workers within the company, yet HR chalks it up to a communication issue. She is a bully. 4. Having worked for several large companies, this is by far the worst employment experience I've ever had.

pros: Michael Dell called my desktop twice during my tenure at Dell. The first time was to make sure I would be viable after I volunteered to take a furlough. Mr. Dell also assured me he would pay me back. The second time, he called to yell at me for a customer escalation. I did fix it.
cons: Before coming to Dell and during my tenure I had established with linux kernel developers via the linux kernel mailing list. I was able to use my relationship between Dell Engineering and the opensource team to make introduction and solve problems for Dell. I gained a lot of visibility with both teams. Under duress a Dell leverage my relationship with the linux team and donated servers for the mailing linux. The trade off was, linux kernel team deleted all traces of my contribution to the linux kernel from the archive. The reasoning was because they, in my opinion, was they felt threaten because at the time I was a low level employee, and could leverage the major players for the linux kernel. This went all the up to a VP level. Dell culture is one that they will hire anyone regardless of education. However, a lot of people feel very insecure about the jobs. Before, I left the company, various account teams leveraged me a lot to resolve the customer escalation. I worked a very high level, and all my customer escalation were resolved. I was there "goto guy". The reason for the review is since, After, I left the company for a number of years on the Dell EMC companies recruited me for a performance engineer job. It would have been great to show my linux contribution history.

Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Nice benefits. Great work culture. Focus on innovation. Diversity.
Cons
More directors and managers. Very few core technical people. Hiring is completely based on the referrals and more and more relatives, friends with non technical people every where specially in Dell IT and edell area. Technical people are not getting treated good and getting paid less where as people who just fill the excel sheets with same information everyday getting higher salaries. All the senior level directors are hiring a lot of contractors not to save money but they are getting their cut from vendors. Millions of dollars are just getting wasted in wrong implementations of projects. Nexus between the senior level management to appreciate each others so that they are able to move from one group to another group. Wrong presentation and representation to the CEO level. Less work more politics. No accountability. Hundreds of emails for silly issues. If you write code you have no respect in Dell but if you are a person who can talk all non sense and create PPT's and excel sheets, which after 3 months doesn't make sense you will be top shot.

review_title: Too much management, not enough talent.
pros: Profitable company that distinctly has a financial future.
cons: There seems to be no real distinct Dell culture, outside of the traces of culture that float around from other companies it has acquired. For the most part the company is embodiment of the old IBM stereo-typical "shirt and tie" business model that died with the boom of tech startups. Dell seems to be demonstrating a desire to prove that it can manage the merger of companies that it acquires regardless of how much mind-share/talent/culture it looses during the acquisition. At one point in time we had 1 Manager and 2 Project Managers overseeing the work of 6 IT administrators. All the while we were being told that our future would be pivoting the focus to process/procedure over productivity/performance.

pros: Best culture code from all companies that I work for. Career growth. Community Engagement is part of our performance indicators. Management, Ethics.

pros: Great benefits, work from home/flexible schedule, competitive pay
cons: Dell prides itself on being a meritocracy; promoting based on merit, but they can't always live up to it. My experience was I worked in a small group of 70 employees and that group was only allowed to promote one individual in a given year due to the internal politics of promotions/budgets. I was on the promotion track and leading up to my end of year review was told I was doing everything required to be promoted to the next pay level. Then when the year ended I was not promoted and was told it was because there are so many talented people in my group the promotion had to go to XYZ person. I did work in an amazing group with top-knotch people, but when the company limits how many promotions they can assign due to budgets based on group size that isn't in line with their meritocracy philosophy.

review_title: Worst edtech corporate job I have ever had
pros: I did make a few colleagues that had the same passion as I did in the k12 learning space, and they too have since departed Dell from a sales and edtech team stand point.
cons: The environment is extremely toxic across most teams. It is a truly a good ole boy culture/network. Little to no advancement for women, and women are devalued due to their "leaning in" of sharing their intelligent knowledge and ideas. Women's ideas are taken and education male team members reclaim them as their own. Leadership on the global and national perspective from the k12 educational team is male driven with little to no classroom or k12 leadership experiences. The male dominant team have been out of the classroom role for more than 15+ years, making their leadership styles, views and k12 education voice stale and irrelevant. The women members of the k12 education are the worker bees and are viewed as the mandatory doers of the delegated task lists. If you want to kill your creativity and have your professional character and image devalued quickly as an educator, then you would be the right fit on this disjointed k12 education team. They need to do some major housecleaning/ vetting of the male leaders and directors to make change and to be truly respected in the k12 teaching and learning space.

ltant in Austin, TX
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Dell name looks good on your resume Michael Dell has decided to move to the Data Center market, lap tops are still a core business. Moves at glacier pace/slow due to being a global company- must follow the process no matter how inane it might be If you can last here at an "IT" company longer than 6 years...you have learned the "Dell way--nuances" They like to hire from within Dell because the internal hires have learned these nuances... you don't say it, you just KNOW what they are insinuating. Interesting place. HR and Talent Acquisition are "trying" to allow employees to work remote, but most business groups won't allow this. You can be wandering the campus, but they want you see you around.
Cons
Politics- ugh! Salaries low for IT company Is A private company, so unlike most IT companies, they do not offer-- stock options as part of a package just a 8, 10 or 15% annual bonus to your salary. To compensate for lack of stock, they offer the engineers an additional bonus called LTI. Managers are so concerned about hurting people's feelings that communication isn't really "real"- you get the double talk. Felt like a had a new direct manager every 3-6 months. There for 2+ years.

review_title: Got gobbled up in an acquisition
pros: Huge customer base. Desire to succeed. Willing to do what it takes to win.
cons: While the culture was mostly toxic, I was in Enterprise Sales, so I was less effected. Until EMC decided months a huge deal, to pay my commissions at 50% months after they accepted the $20M+ PO. This was AFTER sign off from the CEO on the deal. A company willing to do anything to win, will also screw its employees.

ltant
31 May 2017 - Managing Director in Round Rock, TX
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Work/life balance is pretty fair depending on the department. The cafeteria food has a healthy variety, and the fitness facilities are good for the monthly investment.
Cons
Dell fosters a toxic culture in which screaming at subordinates is considered strong. If you're with the "in" crowd, then almost nothing you do in the name of "driving for results" could be bad. It's a mercenary environment to say the least. Personal insults made via faceless phone calls and email terrorism maintain the politics of fear. The core message is: there is a long line of people that are more educated and willing to work for half your salary; keep looking over your shoulder. You could be the victim of the regular, quarterly Workforce Reduction at any moment.

review_title: A siloed and clunky management system of governance
pros: Great Benefits, and an amazing severance plan!
cons: Management was often forced to read the corporate management slides quarterly. They'd read the text, and click next for each slide. When this first happened I thought it was a joke. There was no emotion, and silent giggles as they tripped over the words. Management was driven by a 'What you were not doing" approach to motivation rather than "What are you doing right?" approach. Very negative culture. This eventually sucked the life out of me, and I ended up following a "Cover your arse" approach to work. I lost my adventurism and risk taking approach within two years of being there. They would do reviews based on what your junior peers were saying about you, and not what you actually did.

review_title: Sales Specialist - data storage, servers and networking
pros: compensation if you are there long enough is very good. Better online training now that EMC is in the mix. Good products which customers like.
cons: In sales they move you into new positions without consulting you. This happened in 2016 like every 90 days or so.For example, they would often change selling roles from a pure sales specialist to a technical consultant even though you may not be a very technical type like a systems engineer. You have no choice in this movement, you either accept the new role or leave. Quotas are huge and basically unattainable. They change your account list at the drop of a hat. So the hard work you put into an account can be yanked away in 90 days. Dell says that they want their sales force to be considered "trusted advisors" by their customers, but not really. 70% of sales people are on a performance plan at Dell at any point of time. Dell acquired EMC in 2016 and has taken over the sales process. The inside and outside sales people at Dell are top notch and pounded for numbers. Lastly, delivery on components can be a big problem. Dell had multiple months of notice on this coming component shortage problem and didn't plan well. The sales people suffered the pain and lost many sales due to this since Dell couldn't ship the necessary parts.

cons: Very large company Can be siloed Mix bag of people who have "settled" and those who want to drive hard

Daily targets with daily calls to explain what you're doing to hit your target. Constantly being moved from accounts with no opportunity to build relationships and pipeline. review_title: The good, the bad & the Dell
pros: In my 6 years at Dell, I enjoyed working there, fantastic product and services portfolio and as a successful AE was empowered to make decisions in front of customers which I would encourage Dell support more. Was lucky to work with and for some great managers and GMs.
cons: For an IT 'Solutions Provider' there is far to much focus spent on the CRM tools which consumed an inordinate amount of time for a sales organisation in my opinion. Also drove the wrong behavior among many team members in order to achieve unrealistic weekly KPIs. Biggest negative for me was not being compensated on a large deal which I still find totally unacceptable. This isn't the forum to air my personal grievances but I would suggest that before doing what you think is right for Dell and working on large projects that you get written confirmation of exactly how you will be compensated upon the deal coming in.

pros: Brand recognition, able to enter the tech field without much experience due to training. Great environment to gain knowledge and insight about computers. Continued learning with certificate earning. Great benefits.
cons: Dell has very low retention rates because they micro-manage and under appreciate their employees. The micro-managing is from top level down exploiting the employee and over demanding. They do not pay for everything that you're doing and the L2's 9/10 times are not helpful and get upset when you ask for help constantly as you're trying to learn. Metrics are messed up. If you're out of town for vacation, your metrics keep running and lower your numbers which affect you, Your CE is a apart of your metrics which does not help. For example, if a customer is upset because you can't send out a hard drive because of policy rules, the customer can then review you and give you a 1 on your rating from 1 to 10 and bring your CE down massively just because you were following the rules. Management rarely backs you up and management is terrible. There are some pretty terrible managers out there some who do not have the proper training to lead. Your metrics can go down by simply doing your job. If a customer hangs up the phone, you have to call them back and you get bad metrics for returning a call. How is it your fault that the customer disconnected the phone? If the customer calls back in for whatever reason even though you're continuously emailing him/her, you get metrics hit. The metrics prevent you from succeeding there to your full potential. Not much career advancement. Extra hard work and effort is not recognized so half the time you're making the same as the guy who is just sliding by at work. People quit 3-4 months in the job so you're always having to help train the newbees. No work life balance at all. If you're going in at work at 9:00AM and suppose to get off at 6PM, you might not get off until 8:00PM. You can literally receive a call 30 seconds before you're suppose to get off and you can't transfer the call so you really can't make commitments because you never know when you're going to get off. You can get in trouble for needing to use the restroom because of ACD. A lot of employees develop anxiety and have high stress levels because of this job and people are truly underappreciated. Senior Management always states that "this is the most difficult job in the company" and understand that they are underpaying their employees.

review_title: Dell strategy good, tactically in chaos
pros: Dell is a great place to work, the people are great, the culture is very consensus oriented, and they believe in the community. Job opportunities are abundant where investment is deemed necessary, though much of this seems very short-term given the amazing growth and changes Del is going through.
cons: Strategy seems sound, but tactically many organizations are in chaos. There is no strategic top to bottom. More top is strategy, bottom is pure tactics. Like many corporations there is very filtered discussion around strategy. Sharing challenges, cons or other areas of problems is not shared well. The culture focuses on the pros. The open door policy is good when the news is good, otherwise best to keep to yourself. 2 things truly bother me here. Firstly, there is little strategic planning across BUs (including cross-selling GTM activities), and little if any from the Executive Director level down. Much of what occurs below VPs appears to be very reactive. This affects people greatly, often having to "work around" process issues, system issues and departmental dysfunction.

pros: The best part about working at Dell is the flexibility to work from home and own your schedule. I find that I am much more productive when working from home and I appreciate having this option. It makes managing my work and home life more simple. I also think we have truly inspiring leaders at Dell. My leader has always provided the right level of autonomy and support.
cons: Lots of change, not enough opportunity for merit salary increases

pros: Nothing specifically stands out as a pro - Its not all negative. Its a large company with good people. I am disappointed that Executive leadership does not do more to lead and challenge new areas.
cons: Embraced Welch ideas on cost without the focus on building something new (market, technology, business)

pros: This feedback is for EMC. Used to be a great company for both customers and employees. Of course, the leadership was not aligning properly with investor expectations and failed to cope up with emerging technologies like cloud. Nevertheless, it was a great company for both performers as well as non-performers :) ....that's really the right way to put it. Dell seems to be only interested in cutting cost by laying off people. Of course, they acquired with a cost takeout strategy and they seem to be doing well in that respect.
cons: Dell leaders carrying out integration seem to be only working for their own function's narrow efficiency targets while giving a damn to what impact it is having on the overall "value" for the company. They are destroying value much more than what they are creating. Someone saves a couple of hundred thousand dollars for their "narrow function". Funnily, they don't care that in this process they destroy some couple of million dollars worth value for the company. The way they function, they can't even know. They will really wonder what hit them from where when they wake up between 18 to 24 months from now.

pros: Dell is a great company to work for. The level of learning that i got from Dell, I am still utilization those skills in my roles and new Org. Dell makes you learn a lot every day. cons:
mer or Enterprise) Career wise, the kind of opportunities you can explore in Dell is incomparable and you will surely find one appealing to you. This is the major reason for people sticking to it for more many years. I worked for 10 years for one of this reason :-) Performance based culture. More you perform, better you are and more is your increments & rewards. And Vice versa. I like this kind of environment as it brings the best in everyone instead of Manager or subjective based recognition. No Biasness, only your performance speaks for you
Cons
Benefits and Compensation wise, Dell really need to improve a lot Dell's competitors in the same space are providing far better salaries and benefits than Dell Work also keeps you on your toes all the time. Depending on the LOB, you are aligned it varies. However, overall work will always keep you busy all day Dell is very dynamic in taking tough and bold decisions like Lay Offs, Voluntary separation, selling businesses, no hikes, etc.

review_title: Low pay, long hours, no advancement, but telecommuting options are there
pros: EMC encourages telecommuting and doesn't mind employees working from home. They offer lots of training and free certification tests.
cons: The work life balance can get out of control. I work days and nights and weekends. My schedule is only supposed to cover 40 hours a week but I have not seen a typical 9-5 work week in months. I'm on-call constantly and woken up in the middle of the night frequently. EMC offers flexible vacation days but I dread taking a day off and having to catch up on everything. The compensation is fair when you are hired in but five years down the road I'm barely making anything more than I was when I was hired. I live in fear of getting laid off in one of the frequent firing sprees that has been going on with the Dell EMC merger. I've seen good people come and go as management shifts around. It seems that EMC tries to do more with less and whenever someone leaves it is on the rest of the already overworked coworkers to pick up the slack.

Deploying a new version to production is a pain in the neck, and could take weeks.

review_title: Little chance for growth with little to no culture...
pros: +Work/life balance can be good... +Most of the folks are nice, but... +Nice amenities like a built in cafeteria and in house nurse.
cons: -Most folks are nice, but they rarely want to make conversation. Not saying we need to be friends, but the team I was on felt lifeless at times as everyone just wanted to work and go home. -The offices and rooms lack imagination and have "dull" lighting that dampens the mood. -Work/life balance can become terrible at times. Working 10-12 hours a day for long stretches. A lot of it due to not enough resources on the team. -Health insurance is awful. One of the worst I've seen and pathetic for a big as company as this. -Two weeks vacation is "average" for an American company, but falls behind the more progressive Tech companies. -Very little growth for the company results in very little growth promotion and pay wise. -Pay is pathetic compared to other competitors. I'm currently making 13k more at my current gig with a "lesser" title.

review_title: Despicable Management @ Dell India Tech Support
pros: None I can think of to make it 20 words long.
cons: Dell EMC merger is a big joke and hope the EMC management replaces whole of Dell. There is no transparency in the hiring process. The HRs are totally unprofessional. Self-serving management who promote whomever they like and IJPs are all fixed before they are released. Regionalism, Casteism, add any evil-ism run rampant. Betting on an Employee's skill is fine, but betting on someone's personal life is totally unethical. Spying on employees to try and tarnish their image. And then keep fabricating and make up stuff to support it. Keep refreshing it every 3 months to maintain the image so that it doesn't leave even if one leaves the organization. Flip flop culture to make it look nimble like a startup. The political alignment keeps changing to favor the management. The top management of global support and deployment are overpaid and have no clue what happens on the floor and just don't care. 'Am I safe' is the management mantra. The managers and their crony employees go to extreme length to make sure they are safe in the organization. Some of the site managers think they own the employees just because they have some old MBA degree and graduated out of IIM. They seem more like a by-product of IIM.

review_title: Great company to work for, but...
pros: In terms of benefits and culture, Dell was one of the best companies I ever worked for. Their policies are very family-friendly, and they provided a generous package of vacation, days off for other needs, 401K, healthcare, etc. I was dubious about the prospects of working for Dell when they acquired my company, but it turned out to be a mostly positive experience. I'm sorry my 3 years there ended.
cons: Like any large company, Dell has internal bureaucracies that are inefficient and often maddening. The timecard system is decades old, slow, and unstable; the security policies, such as changing passwords every 60 days, are nonsensical; etc. But my biggest complaint stems from their decision to enter the software business, acquiring companies left and right, and then deciding to abandon software, laying off hundreds of people and divesting the remaining pieces. Hardware companies have the wrong DNA to do software, and Michael Dell should have known this. The acquisitions followed by layoffs damaged careers and destroyed good products. Dell did a disservice to many people through this "experiment".

ltant in Austin, TX
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Reasonably good benefits although they are not as inexpensive as they should be considering Dell's size. Lots of good people doing good work.
Cons
Can be stable, long term employment. But there are reductions across business units frequently so there is underlying fear in long term stability. Lots of good people here but there is a constant struggle to get anything of substance done due to the bureaucracy and silos across global Dell.

pros: As with all companies, it comes down to your leader. I was fortunate to have a leader that was very experienced at navigating the Dell machine and made sure that I achieved the milestones necessary to move along my career path over the few years I reported into him. Raises and bonuses were great (again, it comes down to your leader). I'm now in management. The 401K matching is great, the medical benefits were ok... a bit on the expensive side when compared to my spouses that works at a similar sized company.
cons: 1. Dell is a machine and unless you know have to navigate through this machine, it can take forever to get something done. 2. Spans and layers; at least 8 direct reports to be a manager 3. Non-industry standard career level titles; Sr. Consultant or Sr. Advisor are sound as if you aren't an actual employee but in fact are higher level individual contributor roles 3. Because there's opportunity to transfer to other roles internally, there aren't very many SME's (subject matter experts); it takes a room full of people to get anything done - I come from a smaller acquisition company where having a full understand of a process or program was not uncommon. 4. Dell doesn't provide "free coffee"... the provide the Flavia Machine but the employees have to bring their own k-cups LOL

pros: Great Company to work for. Excellent benefits, Culture is inclusive. Management encourages growth and provides opportunities to move around internally to learn.
cons: As with any large organization, you can get lost in the shuffle if you do not make yourself stand out, Do not get too comfortable in one position.

cons: They are extremely slow to change or allow for outside the box thinking. Still stuck with old tech thinking. "Where technology goes to die."

pros: Great leadership and good benefits. it is a strong sales environment to work, Good company that has historically had great technology for all kinds of solutions inside the data center and robo. Transition from EMC to Dell EMC was executed with not too many bumps and bruises. There has been some reduction in head count, but they are changing in the day of companies moving to the cloud and re-organizing to be more aligned. With Dell servers it aligns very well with changes to more software defined /HCI.
cons: future changes are unclear. more pressure from public cloud vendors and startup AFA vendors create more challenges for quota.

pros: - Dell pays for any necessary IT certifications. -Senior technical support people sit on the same floor, so they are very accessible - people from other technical teams are also on the same floor, making it easy to confer - Dell is rapidly expanding and buying up other companies, many opportunities available.
cons: - Dell puts a huge amount of emphasis on the customer satisfaction score (VOC). The score given by customers is a very important employee metric. However, the feedback given by customers is often not actually acted upon, which makes it feel like a waste of everyone's time. No straightforward way to request deletion / editing of low quality articles in the internal knowledge base, which means low quality articles accumulate

pros: After having such a successful intern experience and seeing how much Dell values their staff, I knew Dell and more specifically Dell’s Supply Chain Graduate Development Program was the right place for me to kick start my career. I wanted to work in an organization that valued me and this is something that Dell has done from day one. My job in Dell goes well beyond my day to day role. By getting involved in onsite groups, I have been able to use my Marketing expertise to get experience in areas that I would love to grow my Dell career in such as event management, PR and blogging. I was surprised at how much interest the company has in its graduates and interns. I knew Dell had a reputation as being a great place to work but Dell is actively involved in caring for its new hires and really promoting employee growth and learning. That is something that is important to me as I try to build my career. I was also pleasantly surprised to see how much Dell values diversity among employees and their ways of thinking. Dell wants graduates and interns to bring new and fresh ideas to the table and no idea is ever too big, small or out-landish that it can’t be considered.
cons: Nothing to share at this time

review_title: Solid workplace, good employees often poached.
pros: Culturally, the place feels positive and solid in the teams I have worked under. I haven't encountered toxic workplaces here. The company seems fairly pro-employee, and you'll encounter employees that have had long runs of employment with the company. Vacation time policy, sick time, 401k-match all feel like good benefits, and the company puts in effort to cultivate employees if the company direction has to change or the employee is struggling.
cons: Raises within a position are very small or nonexistent here - if you want to increase your pay after entering a position, you'll need to either change positions or leave the company if internal advancement is not possible. When changing positions, there's a 'cap' on the possible increase in salary - because this exists, an externally-hired employee could be offered more than a better-qualified internally-hired employee for a given position. This combined with stagnant raises can undermine the statement of 'meritocracy' they drive internally. Overall company direction has been very acquisition-heavy, but they haven't made the most of the acquisitions they've paid for. This feels like it may be sourced from a lack of agility that can often come with being a large company, but that's an externally-positioned viewpoint.

pros: Dell truly cares about growing its workforce within their field. They encourage, and eventually demand that you pursue continuing education, adding certifications to your resume at a rapid pace, which Dell pays for in full. Working at Dell, you could become capable enough to run your own IT department. They strongly encourage you to try out other departments, and to try to move up. cons: Unlike tech employees, the sales force has very little job security. In lean periods, which happen suddenly, Dell lays of hundreds of sales reps, regularly.

ltant in Round Rock, TX
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Passionate and smart co-workers, fast-paced, focus really is on delivering the best experience for customers. Very complex operations with few centralized or documented processes - but teams work with openness and transparency. Dell employee culture (at headquarters) is unique, the only place I've ever worked where co-workers openly share information and are happy to answer any questions or work to help find an answer if they don't know. Employees are empowered to make decisions and propose solutions from the bottom up. Work from home focus brings freedom and allows people to do their best work in the setting most suited to them while keeping balance between home and life.
Cons
Complex operations with few centralized or documented processes can get in the way of delivery. (Even though that also leads to opportunities.) Changes to culture with merger are bringing top-down marching orders and secrecy where openness and empowerment once lived.

pros: Opportunity for growth and learning
cons: Management does not listen to / think of employees when making decisions. Could be from removing benefits to relocating offices. Worklife balance is 'on your own', under management discretion. In short, answer your emails all the time.

review_title: poor pay, loads of favotism in promoting/hiring
pros: Work from home, benefits are ok but not great, mostly respect my peers but variable. Some decent training on your own, not too much micro managing.
cons: Lousy managers/director levels in HR/especially Americas Talent Acq. Loads of favoritism when promoting by the Americas TA leader, she hires/promotes from Perot only regardless of best person for the job. Pay lousy, no raises & minimal bonuses for 3 yrs in a row except for leaders, execs.... shameful!

review_title: Fairly good benefits. Pro remote. Average pay.
pros: Benefits are fairly good, but not great. My one health plan option went from PPO to HMO, for slightly higher premiums. PTO is also also fair, but not "market leader". Company is very pro telecommuting.
cons: Compensation is not 'market leading'. Raises are around 3% for stellar performers. Management does little to retain talent. Pretty stingy with training and travel dollars.

review_title: Inside Sales - It's all about THE NUMBER
pros: Dell has some of the best technology in the market. Reputable brand name Great vision for IT and the market Good leadership (Michael Dell) If you work hard and have a good work ethic you will be successful.
cons: Mysterious quota calculations - no one can tell you how your quota is calculated Commissions - TTC is based on 100% attainment of quota which is near to impossible. Success Tax - if you over attain expect to be hit with a quota success tax that is astronomical Politics and the Rat Race - it is exhausting You are only a number and you are there to hit a number. There is no quality selling skill needed to work here

pros: Historical Culture, Products, Employees - EMC had a great culture of doing what needed to be done to succeed. In the past, all employees shared in the success of the company.
cons: As a long term employee it was tough to see the way EMC has changed. It became very political and didn't offer the same opportunity for lower level employees as it once did. Employees continue to be the management answer to cost savings and greater profitability.

review_title: Used to be a Fantastic Company
pros: Benefits are great, week off during Christmas time, good resume builder
cons: When I first started at Dell, I absolutely loved my job. It took a bit to build my pipeline and learn the business, but once I got rolling, it was great. There were stressful parts of it at times of course, but that is expected in sales positions. Quotas were attainable if you worked really hard and growth was completely realistic. If you worked hard, met your quota and were a good employee, you could advance and move up in the company. Upper management were great, and were always offering extra added incentives to boost employee satisfaction and morale, and give incentive to work harder. A lot has changed in the past two years and the company is no longer even close to the same culture it was in the beginning of my career with Dell. The pressure from upper management was at an all time high, I had some of the most incredible managers when I started here, all of which have since moved on as a result of the new culture that has been created. I have seen several people, extremely good reps that have been with the company 10+ years, get let go last year, and Dell hire a new person to take over those accounts as a level I when the account set requires a level III or IV person to manage it. I had also witnessed several territories get split up and added to different rep's territories and the reps who were previously in those territories, get let go in blink of an eye. I understand the merger brings layoffs and they must cut the slack in certain areas, but I saw several very good reps, that made a lot of money for the company and knew their business extremely well, get let go, when there were other available positions they could have moved them into. From my observation, there seemed to be a lot of this going on in an effort to make cost cuts from the EMC merger. They were also in the process of changing the base/commission split from 70/30 to 60/40 when I left the company. There had been so much added pressure at the end, from what we were told, in an effort to weed people out. It was extremely difficult, almost impossible to move up into a higher role, or even from an ISR II to ISR III. This feeling was mutual throughout the my whole floor, my entire team was looking for a new career at the end of my time there, including several managers. I hope this is culture is only temporary through the merger as I think they have the potential to be incredibly successful as DellEMC if they make some serious changes.
